title: Heyward v. Christmas
description: Esau Heyward was accidentally shot by South Carolina Highway Patrolman Heyward Christmas during an arrest of Heyward by Christmas.  Two issues were resolved by the court, i.e., (1) whether the conduct of South Carolina Highway Patrolman Christmas was objectively reasonable under an analysis pursuant to 42 U.S.C. section 1983; and (2) whether South Carolina Highway Patrolman Christmas was entitled to qualified immunity under the defense of qualified immunity as articulated by Saucier v. Katz, a United States Supreme Court opinion.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
      Esau Heyward, Appellant,
v.
      Samuel Christmas, Respondent.
      
    
  

 

Appeal From Sumter County
Â L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3562
Heard October 9, 2002 â€“ Filed November 
  4, 2002

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Dwight Christopher Moore, of Sumter; John D. Delgado and 
  Kathrine H. Hudgins, both of Columbia, for appellant.
John E. James, III and George C. James, Jr., both of 
  Sumter; for respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Esau Heyward brought a civil 
  action against Samuel Christmas, a South Carolina Highway Patrol trooper, alleging 
  causes of action for negligence, assault and battery, and violation of 42 U.S.C. 
  Â§ 1983 by using excessive force in arresting Heyward.Â  The circuit court granted 
  Christmas a directed verdict.Â  Heyward appeals, arguing that (1) the circuit 
  court erred in granting Christmas a directed verdict; and (2) the circuit court 
  erred in finding Christmas was entitled to qualified immunity.Â  We reverse and 
  remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
 On February 16, 1996, Heyward worked until 5:00 p.m., changed clothes, 
  and then went to a bar called Scottyâ€™s Shop in Pinewood, South Carolina. Heyward 
  drank a few beers and then asked Ronald Brunson to give him a ride home around 
  8:30 to 9:00 p.m.Â  Brunson left Scottyâ€™s with Heyward, and sometime during the 
  drive, shots were exchanged between Brunson and a Pinewood police officer.Â  
  A high-speed chase ensued, and Christmas and Trooper Raffield, another highway 
  patrol trooper, joined the chase.Â  Brunson eventually stopped the car and surrendered 
  to the police.Â  Heyward remained in the car.Â  With his gun drawn, Christmas 
  instructed Heyward to get out of the car and raise his hands.Â  Heyward did not 
  comply.Â  With his gun still drawn, Christmas went to the driverâ€™s side of the 
  vehicle while the other two officers approached Heyward from the passenger side.Â  
  From the driverâ€™s side door, Christmas reached over, grabbed Heyward, and dragged 
  him from the car.Â  As he was pulling Heyward from the vehicle, Christmasâ€™ drawn 
  gun discharged and Heyward was shot in the right leg.Â  The officers did not 
  find a gun in Heywardâ€™s hands.Â  
Heyward filed the underlying civil action against Christmas, alleging causes 
  of action for negligence, assault and battery, and using excessive force in 
  arresting Heyward in violation of 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983.Â  Christmas moved for summary 
  judgment on the negligence claim, and the circuit court granted it.Â  Prior to 
  trial, Heyward agreed to dismiss the assault and battery claim.Â  The only issue 
  to go to trial was whether Christmas had used excessive force in arresting Heyward 
  in violation of Â§ 1983.
 The first witness for Heyward was Christmas.Â  Christmas admitted 
  the sirens from the three police cars would have made any audible instructions 
  to Heyward difficult to hear.Â  Christmas testified that Heywardâ€™s empty hands 
  came up when Christmas grabbed for him.Â  Christmas stated that Heyward did not 
  resist, but his weight of 120 pounds caused Christmas to stumble while pulling 
  Heyward out of the car.Â  Christmas was wearing gloves at the time, and when 
  Heywardâ€™s weight shifted, Christmas maintained that he regripped the gun and 
  the gun discharged.Â  Christmas kept his gun drawn because his brand new holster 
  had not been broken in, which made the holster stick and difficult to pull the 
  gun out.Â  Christmas acknowledged the normal procedure was for the officer to 
  stay in a protective position while ordering occupants of a car to exit one 
  at a time.Â  Christmas affirmed that he did not intentionally shoot Heyward.
Heyward called Rick Johnson as an expert in the field of law enforcement.Â  
  Johnson regarded Christmasâ€™ actions as unreasonable.Â  Johnson contended that 
  Christmas placed himself in jeopardy by approaching the vehicle immediately 
  upon the stop before taking time to assess the situation.Â  Johnson opined that 
  Christmas placed the other officersâ€™ lives in jeopardy by approaching and entering 
  the vehicle with his weapon drawn and by pulling Heyward across to the driverâ€™s 
  seat with one hand when the other officers were standing outside the passenger 
  door.Â  According to Johnson, the more reasonable approach would have been to 
  get in a protected position and use the police carâ€™s public announcement system 
  to give verbal commands to the occupant of the car.
Heyward testified at trial regarding the shooting.Â  According to Heyward, 
  he paid Brunson five dollars to drive him home from the bar.Â  As the two began 
  traveling away from the bar, a police car pulled in behind them.Â  Brunson began 
  shooting at the police car, stating that the police were â€œmessing with him.â€Â  
  Heyward asked Brunson to let him out of the vehicle, but Brunson continued to 
  drive.Â  When the car eventually stopped, Heyward asserted there was a lot of 
  noise coming from the police sirens.Â  Heyward claimed that he sat with his hands 
  in his lap, still buckled in his seatbelt, after the car stopped because he 
  panicked.Â  Heyward heard an officer yell for him to â€œhold it,â€ and to hold his 
  hands up. Â Heyward professed he cooperated by putting his hands up and then 
  recalled being pulled out of the driverâ€™s side of the car.Â  The next thing he 
  heard was the gun discharging.Â  Heyward said that he never had the chance to 
  unlatch his seatbelt prior to being hauled from the car.
After Heywardâ€™s presentation of evidence, Christmas moved for a directed verdict.Â  
  The circuit court reserved the ruling until all the evidence had been presented.
Terry Proctor testified that he was on duty at the sheriffâ€™s office and was 
  patrolling the road on the evening of the shooting when he heard the radio call 
  around midnight that shots had been fired upon a Pinewood police officer in 
  pursuit of a car.
Captain David E. Florence attested that he was on duty at 
  the Sumter County Sheriffâ€™s Office when he heard the radio call regarding the 
  shots fired on the Pinewood police officer.Â  Florence went to the area to try 
  to intercept the suspect vehicle.Â  Florence pulled his vehicle in front of the 
  suspect vehicle and forced Brunson to stop.Â  Florence established that he and 
  several other officers yelled at the occupants to put their hands in the air 
  and exit the car.Â  Although Brunson, the driver, exited the vehicle, the passenger 
  did not show his hands orÂ  comply with any commands.Â  Florence approached the 
  passenger side of the car, and Lieutenant Bradford opened the passenger door 
  to try to get Heyward out of the car.Â  At that moment, Christmas went inside 
  the car and grabbed Heyward from the driverâ€™s side.
Lieutenant Anthony Bradford asserted that after the vehicle 
  was stopped, he walked over to the passenger side.
Christmas averred that when he approached the vehicle, the 
  driverâ€™s side door was left open from the driverâ€™s exit.Â  He believed he had 
  a better view of inside the car than anyone else and could see the suspect, 
  Heyward, in the car.
Relying on Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386 (1989), 
  and Roy v. Inhabitants of City of Lewiston, 42 F.3d 691 (1st 
  Cir. 1994), the circuit court granted the motion for a directed verdict on the 
  Â§ 1983 action, finding no Fourth Amendment violation based on the objective 
  reasonableness standard and on qualified immunity.Â  The court found the gun 
  discharged accidentally, and thus the court would not consider the gun at all.Â  
  The court based its decision on whether the actual seizure was unreasonable.Â  
  The court found that it was not unreasonable under the circumstances for Christmas 
  to pull Heyward out of the car by dragging him across the driverâ€™s seat.Â  The 
  circuit court held that it would not consider Christmasâ€™ deviation from his 
  training in the directed verdict motion.Â  Heyward appeals. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing an order granting a directed verdict, 
  the appellate court views the evidence and all reasonable inferences from the 
  evidence in a light most favorable to the party against whom the directed verdict 
  was granted.Â  Carson v. Adgar, 326 S.C. 212, 216, 486 S.E.2d 3, 5 (1997); 
  Adams v. G.J. Creel and Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 
  85 (1995).Â  If the evidence is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, 
  a jury issue is created and â€œthe court may not grant a directed verdict.â€Â  Hunley 
  v. Gibson, 313 S.C. 350, 351, 437 S.E.2d 554, 555 (Ct. App. 1993). 
ISSUES

  
    
       I.
       Did the circuit court err in granting a directed 
  verdict to Christmas on the ground that his conduct was objectively reasonable?
    
    
       II.
       Did the circuit court err in granting a directed verdict on 
  the ground that Christmas was entitled to qualified immunity?
    
  

LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Objectively Reasonable Standard
Heyward first argues the circuit court erred in granting 
  a directed verdict based on the finding that Christmasâ€™ actions were â€œobjectively 
  reasonable.â€Â  We agree.
The Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution protects 
  citizens from unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  Congress 
  enacted 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 to allow citizens a private cause of action against 
  state actors who deprive them of a constitutional right.Â  Section 1983 provides: 


[Anyone] who, under color of any statute, ordinance, regulation, 
  custom, or usage, of any State or Territory or the District of Columbia, subjects, 
  or causes to be subjected, any citizen of the United States or other person 
  within the jurisdiction thereof to the deprivation of any rights, privileges, 
  or immunities secured by the Constitution and laws, shall be liable to the party 
  injured in an action at law, suit in equity, or other proper proceeding for 
  redress. . . .Â Â  

42 U.S.C. Â§ 1983 (1996).Â  
Heyward argues he was entitled to redress under 
  Â§ 1983 because Christmas violated his Fourth Amendment rights by using unreasonable 
  force in arresting him.Â  â€œBecause the Fourth Amendment provides an explicit 
  textual source of constitutional protection against [excessive force], that 
  Amendment, not the more generalized notion of â€˜substantive due process,â€™ must 
  be the guide for analyzing these claims.â€Â  Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 
  386, 395 (1989).Â  Thus, a claim that a police officer has used excessive force 
  during a seizure of a person must be evaluated under the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s 
  objective reasonableness standard.Â  Graham, 490 U.S. at 388; Threlkeld 
  v. White Castle Systems, Inc., 201 F.Supp.2d 834, 840 (N.D.Ill. 2002).Â  
  â€œDetermining whether the force used to effect a particular seizure is â€˜reasonableâ€™ 
  under the Fourth Amendment requires careful balancing of â€œâ€˜the nature and quality 
  of the intrusion on the individualâ€™s Fourth Amendment interestsâ€™â€ against the 
  countervailing governmental interests at stake.â€Â  Graham, 490 U.S. at 
  396; accord Jackson v. City of Bremerton, 268 F.3d 646, 651 (9th 
  Cir. 2001) (quoting Graham, 490 U.S. at 396).Â  Although the Fourth Amendment 
  recognizes that police have the right to use some force in making an arrest, 
  courts must look to the totality of the circumstances and determine whether 
  the use of force was â€œreasonableâ€ from the perspective of a reasonable officer 
  in the same situation.Â  Graham, 490 U.S. at 396; Jensen v. City of 
  Oxnard, 145 F.3d 1078, 1086 (9th Cir. 1998); Wicker v. City 
  of Galveston, 944 F.Supp. 553, 558 (S.D.Tex. 1996).Â  Factors to consider 
  in determining reasonableness are â€œthe facts and circumstances of each particular 
  case, including the severity of the crime at issue, whether the suspect poses 
  an immediate threat to the safety of the officers or others, and whether he 
  is actively resisting arrest or attempting to evade arrest by flight.â€Â  Graham, 
  490 U.S. at 396.

[T]he question is whether the officersâ€™ actions are â€œobjectively 
  reasonableâ€ in light of the facts and circumstancesÂ  confronting them, without 
  regard to their underlying intent or motivation. . . . An officerâ€™s evil intentions 
  will not make a Fourth Amendment violation out of an objectively reasonable 
  use of force; nor will an officerâ€™s good intentions make an objectively unreasonable 
  use of force constitutional.Â  

Id. at 397; accord Jensen, 
  145 F.3d at 1086; Anderson v. Branen, 17 F.3d 552, 559 (2nd 
  Cir. 1994).Â  
Because the intent of the officer is irrelevant 
  in the overall analysis of whether the officerâ€™s actions were â€œobjectively reasonable,â€ 
  whether a gun discharges accidentally is of no consequence.Â  A court must instead 
  determine whether the use of the gun was objectively reasonable in light of 
  the surrounding circumstances.Â  See Graham, 490 U.S. at 396 (court 
  must consider whether police officerâ€™s use of force was reasonable under the 
  circumstances); Brower v. County of Inyo, 489 U.S. 593, 598-99 (1989) 
  (it is not practicable to conduct an inquiry into subjective intent; it is enough 
  for a seizure that â€œa person be stopped by the very instrumentality set in motion 
  or put in place in order to achieve that resultâ€).
The circuit court in the underlying case relied 
  heavily upon Roy v. Inhabitants of City of Lewiston, 42 F.3d 691 (1st 
  Cir. 1994).Â  In Roy, two police officers watched as a third officer attempted 
  to serve the intoxicated Roy with a summons outside his home.Â  Roy refused the 
  summons, became angry, entered his home, and returned outside with two steak 
  knives, which he swung about while advancing upon the officers.Â  After unsuccessfully 
  attempting to get Roy to drop the knives, Roy lunged at an officer who shot 
  Roy twice.Â  The First Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the district courtâ€™s grant 
  of summary judgment to the officer, finding that â€œin our view a jury could not 
  find that his conduct was so deficient that no reasonable officer could have 
  made the same choice as [the officer] â€“ in circumstances that were assuredly 
  â€˜tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving. . . .â€™â€Â  Roy, 42 F.3d at 695 
  (quoting Graham, 490 U.S. at 397).Â  
Roy is factually distinguishable from the present 
  case.Â  Whereas Roy was proceeding upon the officers while flailing about two 
  steak knives, Christmas approached a motionless Heyward with his gun drawn from 
  the driverâ€™s side of the vehicle.Â  Although Heyward eventually raised his hands, 
  Christmas continued to point his weapon at Heyward.Â  Despite the fact that other 
  officers were attempting to remove Heyward from the passenger side of the car, 
  Christmas grabbed Heyward, who was still wearing a seatbelt, with one hand and 
  lugged him across the seat of the car while still pointing his firearm with 
  the other hand.Â  Christmas, as a result, was also pointing the firearm at the 
  other officers.Â  
Applying the Graham factors to the present case, 
  the original crime of shooting at a police officer was serious and the officers 
  were not initially sure which suspect in the car was the shooter.Â  However, 
  Heyward posed no immediate threat to the police officers when he was removed 
  from the vehicle because he complied with the officersâ€™ requests to make his 
  hands visible just prior to Christmasâ€™ seizure of him.Â  Moreover, he was not 
  actively resisting arrest or trying to flee.Â  
Further, the circuit court erred by refusing to consider 
  the other circumstances in determining whether Christmasâ€™ actions were objectively 
  reasonable.Â  The circuit court specifically refused to consider the use of the 
  weapon in effectuating the seizure of Heyward because it found the resulting 
  shot accidental.Â  In addition, it does not appear the circuit court considered 
  the other officers within the line of fire or Heywardâ€™s act of surrender by 
  putting his hands up prior to Christmasâ€™ actions.Â  An expert testified that 
  Christmasâ€™ actions were not reasonable under the circumstances.Â  Viewing the 
  totality of the circumstances, there was some evidence that Christmasâ€™ actions 
  could be considered objectively unreasonable.Â  Thus, reviewing the evidence 
  in this case in the light most favorable to Heyward, we find the evidence was 
  capable of more than one interpretation and the circuit court erred in granting 
  a directed verdict.
II. QUALIFIED 
  IMMUNITY
Heyward argues the circuit court erred in directing a verdict 
  for Christmas on the grounds that he was entitled to qualified immunity.Â  We 
  agree. 
While Â§ 1983 provides individuals with a method of seeking 
  monetary compensation against state actors who deprive them of a constitutional 
  right, state actors are given some protection.Â  Government officials â€œperforming 
  discretionary functions generally are granted a qualified immunity and are â€˜shielded 
  from liability for civil damages insofar as their conduct does not violate clearly 
  established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person 
  would have known.â€™â€Â  Wilson v. Layne, 526 U.S. 603, 609 (1999) (citing 
  Harlow v. Fitzgerald, 457 U.S. 800, 818 (1982)); see also Todd v. 
  Smith, 305 S.C. 227, 238, 407 S.E.2d 644, 650 (1991) (quoting Harlow).Â  
  â€œ[T]he first inquiry must be whether a constitutional right would have been 
  violated on the facts alleged; second, assuming the violation is established, 
  the question whether the right was clearly established must be considered on 
  a more specific level. . . .â€Â  Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S. 194, 200 (2001).Â  
  â€œThe relevant, dispositive inquiry in determining whether a right is clearly 
  established is whether it would be clear to a reasonable officer that his conduct 
  was unlawful in the situation he confronted.â€Â  Id. at 202 (citing Wilson, 
  526 U.S. at 615). 
The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals has summarized this 
  test as follows:

Ruling on a defense of qualified immunity therefore requires 
  (1) identification of the specific right allegedly violated; (2) determining 
  whether at the time of the alleged violation the right was clearly established; 
  and (3) if so, then determining whether a reasonable person in the officer's 
  position would have known that doing what he did would violate that right. The 
  first two of these present pure questions of law for the courts.Â  Harlow, 
  457 U.S. at 818, 102 S.Ct. at 2738.Â  The third, which involves application of 
  Harlowâ€™s objective test to the particular conduct at issue, may require 
  factual determinations respecting disputed aspects of that conduct.Â  Anderson 
  v. Creighton, 483 U.S. 635, 646 n. 6, 107 S.Ct. 3034, 3042 n. 6 (1987).

Pritchett v. Alford, 973 F.2d 307, 312 (4th 
  Cir. 1992).
At the end of the trial, the circuit court announced an 
  inclination to grant Christmas a directed verdict based on â€œboth the objective 
  reasonable standards on the Fourth Amendment test and qualified immunity.â€Â  
  However, throughout the directed verdict arguments with counsel, the circuit 
  court only discussed the objective reasonable standard.Â  The circuit court did 
  not discuss why, based on the facts presented, it found Christmas was entitled 
  to qualified immunity.Â  It does not appear from the record that the circuit 
  court performed a qualified immunity evaluation.Â  
Nevertheless, it appears that Heyward presented evidence 
  that would create a question of fact regarding qualified immunity.Â  Heyward 
  was entitled under the Fourth Amendment to be free from seizures effectuated 
  by the use of excessive force.Â  This right was clearly established at the time 
  Christmas approached the motionless Heyward with his gun drawn.Â  Finally, some 
  evidence was presented that a reasonable officer would not have approached Heyward 
  in the manner that Christmas did.Â  The expert testimony at trial at least created 
  a question of fact regarding the reasonableness of Christmasâ€™ actions.Â  Because 
  the circuit court failed to make a reasoned evaluation of whether Christmas 
  was entitled to qualified immunity and Heyward presented evidence which could 
  lead to more than one inference regarding Christmasâ€™ entitlement to qualified 
  immunity, the circuit court erred in granting Christmas a directed verdict based 
  on qualified immunity.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed 
  verdict to Christmas is 
REVERSED AND THE CASE IS REMANDED FOR TRIAL.
CONNOR and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

description: The gravamen of this case involves an analysis of "standing" under the Fourth Amendment.  The "standing" issue is analyzed under a reasonable expectation of privacy.  The court held that Missouri had no reasonable expectation of privacy.  Concomitantly, he did not have standing to assert a violation of the Fourth Amendment.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Appellant,
  v.
Victor Wyatt Missouri, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
H. Dean Hall, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3563
Heard October 8, 2002 â€“ Filed November 
  12, 2002

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Charles M. Condon, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 ANDERSON, J.:Â  The Circuit Court found Victor Wyatt Missouri 
  had â€œstandingâ€ to challenge the drug evidence introduced against him based on 
  a violation of the Fourth Amendment.Â  The State appeals, arguing Missouri did 
  not have â€œstandingâ€ to challenge the drug evidence.Â  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In early 1995, Greenville detectives were investigating 
  a crack cocaine ring.Â  On February 3, 1995, the police obtained a warrant to 
  search the apartment of Curtis Sibert for cocaine.Â  When the police executed 
  the search warrant, they found Missouri in the kitchen standing over a sink, 
  facing a set of triple beam scales.Â  The police discovered a quantity of cooked, 
  crack cocaine inside the sink.Â  Missouri was arrested and charged with trafficking 
  in crack cocaine.
At trial, the lead detective admitted he lied in the affidavit issued 
  in support of the search warrant.Â  Further, according to Missouri, the affidavit 
  omitted exculpatory information.Â  The Circuit Court denied Missouriâ€™s motion 
  to suppress the evidence obtained in the search.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed 
  the Circuit Court, ruling the omitted information was necessary for the magistrateâ€™s 
  finding of probable cause.Â  This Court remanded the matter for a hearing to 
  determine whether Missouri had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the apartment.Â  
  State v. Missouri, 97-UP-448 (S.C. Ct. App. filed September 15, 1997).Â  
  The Supreme Court affirmed.Â  State v. Missouri, 337 S.C. 548, 524 S.E.2d 
  394 (1999).
A hearing was held before the Circuit Court on 
  remand to determine whether Missouri had a reasonable expectation of privacy 
  in the apartment.Â  Sibert, Missouriâ€™s best friend, testified that in 1994 and 
  1995, Missouri was an occasional overnight guest at Sibertâ€™s apartment â€œwhenever 
  [Missouri] got to arguing with his wife,â€ whenever Sibertâ€™s wife would leave 
  for the weekend, and whenever Missouri and Sibert would sneak away to â€œgo partying.â€Â  
  Sibert stated that Missouri kept a change of clothing at Sibertâ€™s apartment 
  so Missouri could â€œgo partyingâ€ with Sibert without Missouriâ€™s â€œwifeâ€ finding 
  out.Â  Missouri would stay in Sibertâ€™s sonâ€™s room whenever he spent the night.
On certain occasions, Sibert would give Missouri 
  a key to the apartment.Â  Sibert declared that Missouri had a key to the apartment 
  at the time of Missouriâ€™s arrest.Â  According to Sibert, Missouri went to the 
  apartment as a friend, not as a business associate, when Sibert was not there.Â Â  
  Sibert left Missouri in control of the apartment when he was gone, with the 
  ability to let people come and go as Missouri saw fit.Â  Because Sibertâ€™s wife 
  was trying to â€œkickâ€ her drug addiction, Sibert testified that he would not 
  have left Missouri in his apartment the day the search warrant was executed 
  if he had known Missouri intended to mix the drugs there.
Sibert admitted on cross-examination that he returned 
  to his apartment at 1:00 a.m. the night before the search warrant was executed 
  and Missouri was not staying there.Â  He did not recall the exact date when Missouri 
  last spent the night at his apartment.Â  Sibert professed he was not in the drug 
  business and that he had no idea what Missouri was planning to do in his apartment 
  when he left Missouri there the day the search warrant was executed.
Sibertâ€™s wife testified Missouri had a key to the apartment, he left a change 
  of clothing there, and he had control of the apartment when she and Sibert were 
  gone.
At the hearing, Missouri stated he was close friends with Sibert 
  and had known him for many years.Â  He occasionally spent the night at Sibertâ€™s 
  apartment.Â  Missouri declared that he was free to come and go from Sibertâ€™s 
  apartment and would sometimes use the key Sibert had given him.Â  Although Missouri 
  had his own residence a few miles from Sibertâ€™s apartment, Missouri would stay 
  at the apartment whenever he was arguing with his fiancÃ©e or whenever he wanted 
  to get out of the house.Â  Missouri stayed in Sibertâ€™s sonâ€™s room and he kept 
  a change of clothes there.Â  However, Missouri admitted that he did not spend 
  the night at Sibertâ€™s apartment the night before the search warrant was executed.Â  
  Missouri denied that he and Sibert had a business relationship regarding drug 
  trafficking. 
The State presented the testimony of Detective Eric Cureton, the officer responsible 
  for the false statements in the affidavit supporting the search warrant.Â  Cureton 
  was conducting surveillance on Sibertâ€™s apartment the day the warrant was executed.Â  
  On that day, he observed Missouri enter the apartment between 2:30 and 3:00 
  p.m. and did not see any other person enter or exit the apartment.Â  The search 
  warrant was executed between 9:30 and 10:00 p.m., after Sibert called the confidential 
  informant to inform him that it was time to â€œcome and get it.â€
Cureton monitored Sibert and his wife purchasing baking soda at different locations 
  around town earlier that day.Â  Baking soda is used to aid in the cooking process, 
  which turns cocaine into crack cocaine.Â  Upon executing the warrant, 
  Cureton discovered Missouri in the kitchen standing over several dishes of cooling 
  crack cocaine.Â  Sibert and his wife were sitting on the couch with the television 
  on.Â  The police examined Missouriâ€™s key chain.Â  It held three keys: one to Missouriâ€™s 
  residence, and two keys to two cars.Â  The key chain did not contain a key to 
  Sibertâ€™s apartment.Â  In the kitchen, Cureton recovered a black bag belonging 
  to Missouri and containing scales and packaging paper.Â  No other items belonging 
  to Missouri were found in the apartment. 
On cross-examination, Cureton professed he was â€œconfusedâ€ and an 
  inexperienced police officer when he drafted the original affidavit in support 
  of the search warrant.Â  Cureton admitted he was not familiar with Missouriâ€™s 
  clothes and did not know whether Missouriâ€™s clothes were in Sibertâ€™s apartment.Â  
  Although Cureton checked the keys on Missouriâ€™s key ring, he returned the keys 
  to Missouri after he was booked.Â  Cureton was not aware of the friendship between 
  Missouri and the Siberts.
 Detective James Bradley testified that, upon executing the search 
  warrant, he found Missouri in the kitchen with cooked crack cocaine.Â  Bradley 
  did not find any items in the apartment belonging to Missouri.Â  When Missouri 
  was searched, â€œsome keysâ€ were â€œtaken off of him.â€Â  The keys went to a van, 
  another car, and Missouriâ€™s residence.
 Missouri testified in reply regarding the keys.Â  He stated he had 
  more than three keys on his key chain. 
The Circuit Court determined that Missouri and Sibert were close, 
  long-time friends and Missouri visited Sibert frequently at Sibertâ€™s apartment.Â  
  Missouri sometimes spent the night at Sibertâ€™s, but did not live with Sibert.Â  
  The court found Missouri had access to the apartment, on some occasions had 
  a key to the apartment, and was free to come and go as he pleased from the apartment.Â  
  Further, the court noted the Siberts did not charge Missouri to stay at their 
  apartment, he kept a change of clothes there, and Missouri used the apartment 
  as a place to â€œâ€˜get away.â€™â€Â  The court specifically found Missouri did not spend 
  the night at the apartment the evening prior to the execution of the search 
  warrant.Â  Finally, the court concluded that, on the day the search warrant was 
  issued, the police began surveillance of the Sibertsâ€™ apartment at 7:00 a.m.; 
  Missouri arrived between 2:30 and 3:00 p.m.; the Siberts left Missouri at their 
  apartment while they went shopping; the search warrant was executed between 
  9:30 and 10:00 p.m.; and the officers discovered Missouri in the kitchen with 
  crack cocaine and the Siberts in another room.
 Based on the factual findings, the Circuit Court held that Missouri 
  had a legitimate expectation of privacy in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment and he would 
  therefore be able to challenge the search under the Fourth Amendment. 
  [1] 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  
  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Cutter, 
  261 S.C. 140, 199 S.E.2d 61 (1973).Â  This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s 
  factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 
  338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000).
Our Supreme Court articulated the proper standard of review in regard 
  to a Fourth Amendment issue relating to search and seizure:

As a threshold matter, we must determine the appropriate 
  standard of review to apply in considering the trial courtâ€™s ruling below. . 
  . . The test for making this determination entails an inquiry into the totality 
  of the circumstances. . . . .
. . . .
Therefore, we will review the trial courtâ€™s ruling like 
  any other factual finding and reverse if there is clear error.Â  We will affirm 
  if there is any evidence to support the ruling.

State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 65-66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 665-66 (2000).Â  
  We find the Brockman standard of review is controlling.
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution elucidates:

The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, 
  papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be 
  violated, and no warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by 
  oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and 
  the persons or things to be seized.

U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  The South Carolina Constitution provides similar protection 
  against unlawful searches and seizures.Â  See S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â  
  Evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment is inadmissible in both 
  state and federal court.Â  See Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 643, 81 S.Ct. 
  1684, 6 L.Ed.2d 1081 (1961); Weeks v. United States, 232 U.S. 383, 34 
  S.Ct. 341, 58 L.Ed. 652 (1914); State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 
  S.E.2d 837 (2001); State v. Austin, 306 S.C. 9, 409 S.E.2d 811 (Ct. App. 
  1991).
Fourth Amendment rights are personal rights which, like some other constitutional 
  rights, may not be vicariously asserted.Â  See Alderman v. United States, 
  394 U.S. 165, 89 S.Ct. 961, 22 L.Ed.2d 176 (1969); Rakas v. Illinois, 
  439 U.S. 128, 99 S.Ct. 421, 58 L.Ed.2d 387 (1978).Â  Thus, a person seeking to 
  have evidence suppressed based upon a Fourth Amendment violation â€œmust establish 
  that his own Fourth Amendment rights were violatedâ€ by the search and seizure.Â  
  State v. McKnight, 291 S.C. 110, 114-15, 352 S.E.2d 471, 473 (1987) (citing 
  United States v. Salvucci, 448 U.S. 83, 100 S.Ct. 2547, 65 L.Ed.2d 619 
  (1980)); see also Rakas, 439 U.S. at 138, 99 S.Ct. at 428, 
  58 L.Ed.2d at 398 (â€œâ€˜rights assured by the Fourth Amendment are personal rights, 
  [which] . . . may be enforced by exclusion of evidence only at the instance 
  of one whose own protection was infringed by the search and seizureâ€™â€).
It is not necessary for a defendant to be an owner of a property in order to 
  claim Fourth Amendment rights.Â  State v. Daniels, 252 S.C. 591, 167 S.E.2d 
  621 (1969).Â  However, a defendant seeking to suppress evidence on Fourth Amendment 
  grounds bears the burden of proving he had a reasonable expectation of privacy 
  in the area searched or the item seized.Â  United States v. Rusher, 966 
  F.2d 868 (4th Cir. 1992) (citing Rawlings v. Kentucky, 448 U.S. 98, 100 
  S.Ct. 2556, 65 L.Ed.2d 633 (1980)); McKnight, 291 S.C. at 115, 352 S.E.2d 
  at 473.Â  â€œA subjective expectation of privacy is legitimate if it is one that 
  society is prepared to recognize as reasonable.â€Â  Minnesota v. Olson, 
  495 U.S. 91, 95-96, 110 S.Ct. 1684, 1687, 109 L.Ed.2d 85, 92 (1990) (internal 
  quotations omitted).
In determining whether a particular defendant may challenge a search and seizure, 
  the United States Supreme Court has indicated a preference for an analysis focusing 
  on â€œthe extent of a particular defendantâ€™s rights under the Fourth Amendment, 
  rather than on any theoretically separate, but invariably intertwined concept 
  of standing.â€Â  Rakas, 439 U.S. at 139, 99 S.Ct. at 428, 58 L.Ed.2d at 
  398; see also State v. Hiott, 276 S.C. 72, 76-77, 276 S.E.2d 163, 
  165 (1981) (â€œthe United States Supreme Court has recently shifted away from 
  a â€˜standingâ€™ approach to an inquiry focusing directly on the substantive issue 
  of whether the claimant possessed a â€˜legitimate expectation of privacyâ€™ in the 
  area searched.â€).
Whether a defendant has a reasonable expectation of privacy in a 
  particular premises depends on the status of the defendant.Â  The Fourth Amendment 
  offers more protection to an overnight guest than to one who is merely a casual 
  guest or conducting a business transaction.Â  In Minnesota v. Olson, 495 
  U.S. 91, 110 S.Ct. 1684, 109 L.Ed.2d 85 (1990), police entered a residence, 
  without a warrant, to apprehend an overnight guest who was a suspect in a murder 
  and robbery.Â  The Supreme Court found the defendantâ€™s status as an overnight 
  guest alone was â€œenough to show that he had an expectation of privacy in the 
  home that society is prepared to recognize as reasonable.â€Â  Olson, 495 
  U.S. at 96-97, 110 S.Ct. at 1688, 109 L.Ed.2d at 93.
By contrast, in Minnesota v. Carter, 525 U.S. 83, 119 S.Ct. 
  469, 142 L.Ed.2d 373 (1998), two defendants were in the apartment of the lessee 
  for the sole purpose of packaging cocaine.Â  The two defendants paid the lessee 
  of the apartment one-eighth of an ounce of cocaine for the two and one-half 
  hours they used the apartment.Â  There was no indication that the two defendants 
  had a prior relationship with the lessee of the apartment.Â  The Supreme Court 
  held that, unlike the overnight guest in Olson, the two defendants in 
  Carter had no reasonable expectation of privacy in the apartment because 
  they were guests â€œsimply permitted on the premisesâ€ and were present solely 
  for a business transaction.Â  Carter, 525 U.S. at 91, 119 S.Ct. at 474, 
  142 L.Ed.2d at 381.
The facts in the present case are more akin to those found in Carter.Â  
  Missouri clearly had a long relationship with Sibert and had periodically been 
  an overnight guest in Sibertâ€™s apartment with the occasional use of a key to 
  the apartment.Â  When Missouri spent the night with Sibert, he was free to come 
  and go as he pleased.Â  However, Missouri was not an overnight guest the evening 
  before the search warrant was executed.Â  Moreover, he had only been present 
  at Sibertâ€™s apartment for a few hours.Â  Despite Missouriâ€™s testimony that he 
  kept clothes in the apartment and that he had a key, neither his clothes nor 
  a key was found.Â  The major purpose of Missouriâ€™s presence was to cook cocaine 
  into crack cocaine.
We find Missouriâ€™s occasional status as an overnight guest did not extend to 
  this instance where he was merely a permittee on the premises.Â  Further, as 
  he was assisting Sibert with the manufacture of crack cocaine, Missouriâ€™s main 
  purpose for being on the premises was for â€œbusinessâ€ reasons.
CONCLUSION
We hold Missouri had no reasonable expectation of privacy.Â  Concomitantly, 
  he did not have â€œstandingâ€ to assert a violation of the Fourth Amendment.Â  
  We rule that, at the time the search warrant was executed, Missouri was merely 
  a permitted guest conducting business, not an overnight guest entitled to Fourth 
  Amendment protection.Â  We REVERSE the Circuit Courtâ€™s finding that Missouri 
  had â€œstandingâ€ to assert a violation of the Fourth Amendment.
 REVERSED.
 STILWELL, J., concurs.
CONNOR, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
 Connor, J. (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent 
  and would affirm the trial judgeâ€™s ruling.Â  I believe Missouri had a legitimate 
  expectation of privacy in the Sibertsâ€™ apartment.Â Â  
As noted by the majority, the trial judgeâ€™s ruling on this issue can only be 
  reversed if there is clear error. If any evidence supports the ruling, it will 
  be affirmed.Â  State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 65-66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 
  665-66 (2000); State v. Williams, Op. No. 3550 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Sept. 
  9, 2002) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 32 at 66).
The majority opinion outlines the numerous findings 
  of fact made by the trial judge. After observing all of the witnesses, the trial 
  judge found Missouri had a legitimate expectation of privacy in the premises 
  searched.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

The trial judge specifically found that Missouri and 
  Curtis Sibert were â€œgood friendsâ€ and had grown up together, and that Missouri 
  frequently visited the Sibertsâ€™ apartment, sometimes spending the night. Moreover, 
  he found that Missouri on â€œsome occasionsâ€ had a key to the apartment and kept 
  a change of clothes there.Â  He also found the Siberts did not charge Missouri 
  to use the apartment.Â  
However, the majority makes its own findings of fact, 
  some contrary to those made by the trial judge.Â  The majority characterizes 
  Missouriâ€™s relationship with the Siberts as that of an â€œoccasionalâ€ or â€œperiodicalâ€ 
  overnight guest.Â  Furthermore, the majority finds â€œneither [Missouriâ€™s] clothes 
  nor a key was foundâ€ in the apartment.Â  It also states the main purpose of Missouriâ€™s 
  presence at the apartment was for â€œbusinessâ€ reasons. 
The United States Supreme Court, in Minnesota v. Olson, 495 U.S. 91 
  (1990), held an overnight guest had a reasonable expectation of privacy. [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On the other hand, in Minnesota v. Carter, 525 U.S. 83 (1998), the Court 
  addressed â€œthe issue of whether a person present in anotherâ€™s home for a â€˜purely 
  commercial . . . transaction,â€™ for only a â€˜relatively short period of time,â€™ 
  and having no â€˜previous relationship withâ€™ the householder, could claim the 
  Fourth Amendmentâ€™s protections.â€Â  Morton v. United States, 734 A.2d 178, 
  180 (D.C. 1999) (quoting Carter, 525 U.S. at 91).Â  The Court said such 
  person did not have a reasonable expectation of privacy. 
In Carter, the Court held there was nothing â€œsimilar to the overnight 
  guest relationship in Olson to suggest a degree of acceptance into the 
  household.â€Â  Carter, 525 U.S. at 90.Â  TheÂ  Court further stated: â€œIf 
  we regard the overnight guest in Minnesota v. Olson as typifying those 
  who may claim the protection of the Fourth Amendment in the home of another, 
  and one merely â€˜legitimately on the premisesâ€™ as typifying those who may not 
  do so, the present case is obviously somewhere in between.â€Â  Carter, 
  525 U.S. at 91. [3] Â Â Â  
I believe this case is more like Olson than 
  Carter.Â  In Carter there was â€œno suggestion that [the defendants] 
  had a previous relationship with [the householder], or that there was any other 
  purpose to their visit.â€Â  Carter, 525 U.S. at 90.Â  In this case Missouri 
  and Sibert were good friends, and Missouri had visited the apartment on a frequent 
  basis, sometimes spending the night. Missouri was free to come and go as he 
  pleased and paid nothing to use the apartment.Â  Missouri had a change of clothes 
  at the apartment and on some occasions had a key.Â  He used the apartment as 
  a place to â€œget awayâ€ and as a place to â€œfind comfort.â€Â  On the day the warrant 
  was executed, Missouri had been at the apartment for approximately seven hours. 
  Additionally, when left alone at the apartment, Missouri could control who came 
  and entered the apartment.Â Â  
The trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact support his ruling 
  that Missouri had a legitimate expectation of privacy in the apartment.Â  This 
  ruling is clearly supported by the evidence. Therefore the trial judge should 
  be affirmed.

 
   [1]  
    The court used the term â€œstanding.â€Â  The United States Supreme Court has indicated 
    a preference for an evaluation of the substantive Fourth Amendment right.Â  
    Accordingly, we will interchange this term for â€œstandingâ€ throughout this 
    opinion.

 
   [2] Â Â  In reaching this conclusion, the Court recognized 
    the facts of Olson were similar to those in Jones v. United States, 
    362 U.S. 257 (1960).Â  Olson, 495 U.S. at 97.Â  Jones is likewise 
    instructive in the present case.Â  The defendant in Jones sought to 
    challenge a search warrant after being arrested in a friendâ€™s apartment.Â  
    Jones testified that â€œthe apartment belonged to a friend . . . who had given 
    him the use of it, and a key, with which [Jones] had admitted himself on the 
    day of the arrest.â€Â  Jones v. United States, 362 U.S. 257, 259 (1960), 
    overruled in part by United States v. Salvucci, 448 U.S. 83 
    (1980) (rejecting the â€œautomatic standingâ€ rule based on possession of seized 
    goods established in Jones).Â  Jones also testified he had clothing 
    in the apartment, â€œthat his home was elsewhere, that he paid nothing for the 
    use of the apartment, that [his friend] had let him use it â€˜as a friend,â€™ 
    [and] that he had slept there â€˜maybe a night[.]â€™â€Â  Id.Â  The Court ruled 
    Jones could challenge the search because he was â€œlegitimately on [the] premises.â€Â  
    Although this particular standard has been repudiated, the Court stated it 
    did â€œnot question the conclusion in Jones that the defendant in that 
    case suffered a violation of his personal Fourth Amendment rights if the search 
    in question was unlawful.â€Â  Rakas v. Illinois, 439 U.S. 128, 141 (1978).Â  
    â€œRakas thus recognized that, as an overnight guest, Jones was much 
    more than just legitimately on the premises.â€Â  Olson, 495 U.S. at 98.Â  
    There is nothing in Jones to indicate the defendant was an overnight 
    guest the evening before the search warrant was executed.

 
   [3] Â Â  The Court in Carter also recognized the 
    continuing validity of the factual â€œholding of Jones â€“ that a search 
    of the apartment violated the defendantâ€™s Fourth Amendment rights.â€Â  Carter, 
    525 U.S. at 89-90.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Daisy Outdoor Advertising Company, Inc.,Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Transportation,Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No.Â  3564
Submitted July 10, 2002 â€“ Filed November 
  12, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert D. Moseley, Jr., of Greenville; for Appellant.
Assistant Chief Counsel Barbara M. Wessinger, of Columbia; 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

__________
HUFF, J.:Â  Daisy Outdoor Advertising Company, 
  Inc. (Daisy) appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the Administrative 
  Law Judgeâ€™s (ALJâ€™s) order upholding the South Carolina Department of Transportationâ€™s 
  (SCDOTâ€™s) revocation of two permits for outdoor advertising signs.Â  We affirm. 
   [1] 
FACT AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Daisy applied for permits for 
  two outdoor advertising signs to be located along I-26 in Spartanburg County 
  in November of 1998.Â  As the signs were to be located in an area without zoning, 
  Daisy was required to identify a qualifying business within 600 feet of the 
  sign sites.Â  The applications listed Quick Response Fire Systems as the qualifying 
  business.Â  On March 31, 1999, SCDOT informed Daisy that the applications had 
  been approved.
In May of 1999, Quick Response 
  ceased its operations at this location.Â  By August of 1999, it had vacated the 
  location, the power had been disconnected, and a â€œFor Leaseâ€ sign had been placed 
  in front of the building.Â  In November of 1999, SCDOT informed Daisy that it 
  was canceling the permits for the signs.
Daisy appealed to the ALJ.Â  The 
  ALJ found SCDOT had established by prima facie evidence that Quick Responseâ€™s 
  activities at the location were a sham as defined in 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 
  63-342 (U) (Supp. 2001).Â  He then found Daisy failed to overcome SCDOTâ€™s prima 
  facie case that Quick Response was primarily situated at this location to qualify 
  the sign site and failed to establish that there was any meaningful business 
  conducted at Quick Response for the requisite one-year period after the approval 
  of the applications.Â  Daisy appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the 
  ALJ.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The standard of review for a court reviewing the decision 
  of an ALJ is set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (D) (Supp. 2001) of the 
  Administrative Procedures Act (APA).Â  The court may not substitute its judgment 
  for that of the ALJ on questions of fact when those facts are supported by substantial 
  evidence.Â  Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (2000).Â  
  Substantial evidence is relevant evidence that, considering the record as a 
  whole, a reasonable mind would accept to support the ALJâ€™s decision.Â  Id.Â  
  It exists when, if the case were presented to a jury, the court would refuse 
  to direct a verdict because the evidence raises questions of fact for the jury.Â  
  Id.Â  Substantial evidence is more than a mere scintilla of evidence, 
  but is something less than the weight of the evidence.Â  Id.Â  Furthermore, 
  the possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does 
  not prevent a court from concluding that substantial evidence supports the ALJâ€™s 
  finding.Â  Id.
DISCUSSION
Daisy argues the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order should be reversed because the ALJ erred in upholding SCDOTâ€™s revocation 
  of the sign permits.Â  We disagree.
In the Highway Advertising Control Act, 
  the General Assembly acknowledged that outdoor advertising is â€œa business which 
  must be allowed to exist and operate where other business and commercial activities 
  are conducted and that a reasonable use of property for outdoor advertising 
  to the traveling public is desirable.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-130 (Supp. 2001).Â  
  However, the General Assembly also recognized that the erection and maintenance 
  of outdoor advertising signs adjacent to the interstate and federal-aid primary 
  systems must be regulated.Â  Id.Â  Thus, it granted SCDOT the authority 
  to issue permits for the erection and maintenance of the signs and to promulgate 
  regulations governing the issuance of the permits.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-150(A) 
  (Supp. 2001). 
Generally, the Highway Advertising Control 
  Act limits the placement of commercial outdoor advertising signs to zoned industrial 
  areas, zoned commercial areas, unzoned commercial areas, or unzoned industrial 
  areas.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-140(7) & (8) (Supp. 2001).Â  An unzoned commercial 
  or industrial area is defined as â€œthe land occupied by the regularly used building, 
  parking lot, and storage and processing area of a commercial, business, or industrial 
  activity and land within six hundred feet of it on both sides of the highway.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-120 (4) (Supp. 2001).Â  Such an area does not include 
  an area occupied by â€œsham activities.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-342(FF)(4) 
  (Supp. 2001).Â  A sham activity is defined as:

any activity that is seemingly 
  a commercial or industrial activity but which was created primarily or exclusively 
  to qualify an area as an unzoned commercial or industrial area and which does 
  not conduct any meaningful business at the activity site.Â  Failure of an activity 
  to maintain the standards set forth under the definition of transient and temporary 
  [2]  within one year after a sign permit was issued based on the activity 
  qualifying the sign site as an unzoned commercial or industrial area shall be 
  prima facie evidence that the activity was a sham.

25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-342(U) 
  (Supp. 2001).Â  Â  If an activity is subsequently determined to be a sham activity, 
  the sign permitted under this activity shall be illegal and must be removed 
  at the sign ownerâ€™s or landownerâ€™s expense.Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-344(G) 
  (Supp. 2001).
Daisy acknowledges in its brief that Quick Response ceased its operations 
  less than one year after the permit approval, and thus, SCDOT established a 
  prima facie case that Quick Response was a sham activity.Â  Once a party establishes 
  a prima facie case, the burden of proof shifts to the opposing party.Â  Hadfield 
  v. Gilchrist, 343 S.C. 88, 538 S.E.2d 268 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The ALJ found 
  Daisy had failed to overcome SCDOTâ€™s prima facie case that Quick Response was 
  a sham activity.Â  We reject Daisyâ€™s contention that the ALJ improperly shifted 
  the burden of proof to Daisy.Â  Furthermore, we find substantial evidence in 
  the record supports the ALJâ€™s finding that Daisy failed to overcome SCDOTâ€™s 
  prima facie case that Quick Response was primarily situated at this location 
  to qualify the sign sites as an unzoned commercial area.
Pursuant to Regulation 63-342(U), Daisy had the burden of coming forward 
  with evidence to show (1) Quick Response was not created primarily or exclusively 
  to qualify the location for an outdoor advertising sign, and (2) it conducted 
  meaningful activity at the site.Â  Daisy asserts it met this burden by presenting 
  evidence that Quick Response was a viable business conducting meaningful business 
  for more than a year before the approval of the sign permits.Â  The issue is 
  not whether Quick Response was a legitimate business, but rather whether its 
  activities at the site were created primarily or exclusively to qualify the 
  site for placement of the signs.
Daisy, whose primary business is outdoor advertising, owns the buildings 
  Quick Response occupied on the site.Â  Daisy and Quick Response entered into 
  the lease on April 23, 1998.Â  The terms of the lease were very favorable towards 
  Quick Response.Â  The rent was only $400.00 a month compared to $1,600.00 a month 
  Quick Response paid at its former location.Â  Daisy continued to pay the electric 
  bills for the site until October 19, 1998, when the electricity was connected 
  in Quick Responseâ€™s name.Â  Quick Response did not reimburse Daisy until eight 
  months later for all of the bills it had paid from April to October.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  There is no 
  dispute that Quick Response conducted its normal business activities at the 
  site from April of 1998 until May of 1999.Â  However, Spartanburg County never 
  issued a certificate of occupancy for the building on the site.Â  Accordingly, 
  no business could legally occupy the structure.Â  SCDOTâ€™s Director of Outdoor 
  Advertising testified that in addition to the closing of the business within 
  one year of the permit, SCDOT considered the fact that Quick Response did not 
  have a permit to occupy the building in determining that no meaningful business 
  occurred at the location.
We next consider whether Quick Response conducted meaningful business 
  at the location.Â  The ALJ held, â€œ[T]he issue is not whether the qualifying business 
  was operational prior to the submittal of outdoor advertising permit applications 
  to SCDOT but rather whether it â€˜maintainedâ€™ meaningful operation after the permit 
  was approved in order to provide evidence of a commercial area.â€Â  Daisy asserts 
  the ALJ improperly held that the time period for measuring whether a qualifying 
  business is conducting meaningful business continues for a period of one year 
  after approval of the permit.Â  It asserts that the operative time in which the 
  business must be evaluated is at the time of the application or during the initial 
  investigation surrounding the issuance of the permits.
â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and fair 
  interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.â€Â  
  TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 
  503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998); see also Whitner v. State, 328 S.C. 
  1, 492 S.E.2d 777 (1997) (stating courts should consider not merely the language 
  of the particular clause being construed, but the word and its meaning in conjunction 
  with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law).Â  â€œThe construction 
  of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded 
  the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling 
  reasons.â€Â  Dunton v. South Carolina Bd. of Examiners in Optometry, 291 
  S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987).Â  Furthermore, an agencyâ€™s interpretation 
  of its own regulation deserves considerable deference.Â  Leventis v. S.C. 
  Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 340 S.C. 118, 530 S.E.2d 643 (Ct. 
  App. 2000).
SCDOT considers the year following the issuance of the permit in determining 
  whether meaningful activities occur at a qualifying business.Â  In promulgating 
  Regulation 63-342(U), SCDOT obviously intended for the entire one-year period 
  following the issuance of the permit to be considered in its evaluation as the 
  failure of the business to maintain the business for that year constitutes prima 
  facie evidence that the activity is a sham.Â  This interpretation is consistent 
  with the Highway Advertising Control Actâ€™s requirement that outdoor advertising 
  signs be limited to unzoned areas of commercial activity.Â  It furthers the purpose 
  of the act, which, in part, is to prevent distraction of operators of motor 
  vehicles, promote the safety, convenience, and enjoyment of travel on highways 
  within this State, and preserve and enhance the natural scenic beauty and aesthetic 
  features of highways and adjacent areas.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-150 (Supp. 
  2001).Â  SCDOTâ€™s Director of Outdoor Advertising explained that if SCDOT did 
  not effectively regulate the activities it permitted as commercial activities, 
  the Federal Highway Administration could penalize the state by withholding up 
  to ten percent of the stateâ€™s federal highway funds.Â  Accordingly, we find no 
  error in the ALJâ€™s interpretation of the regulation.
Considering the record as a whole and the purpose of the Act and regulations, 
  we find substantial evidence supports the ALJâ€™s determination that Daisy did 
  not establish Quick Response conducted meaningful business at the location.Â  
  Thus, we hold the ALJ did not err in ruling that Quick Response was a sham activity 
  under the Highway Advertising Control Act, requiring cancellation of the outdoor 
  advertising permits and removal of the sign structures.
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, 
  J., concur.

 
   [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  Transient or temporary activities are defined as activities that 
    do not have:
  
  (1)Â  at 
    least one employee attendant at the activity site, performing meaningful work 
    and available to the public for at least thirty-six (36) hours per week on 
    at least four (4) days per week for at least forty-eight (48) weeks per year;
  (2)Â  electricity, telephone, 
    running water, indoor restroom, permanent flooring other than dirt, gravel, 
    sand, etc; adequate heating; and
  (3)Â  the activity, or a 
    major portion of it, conducted from a permanent building constructed principally 
    of brick, concrete block, stone, concrete, metal, or wood or some combination 
    of these materials or from a mobile home or trailer which the applicant can 
    prove is considered part of the real estate and taxed accordingly.
  
  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 
    63-342(CC) (Supp. 2001).
