  THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
  
    
      
        
           City of Landrum,        
            Appellant,
        
      
    
  
  v.
   
     
       
         
          Michael 
            James Sarratt,        Respondent.
        
      
    
  
  
  Appeal From Spartanburg County
  Â Gary 
    E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge
  
  
    Opinion No.Â  3569
  September 18, 2002 â€“ Filed November 18, 2002
    
  
   
     REVERSED   
  
  
    
      
        
      Harold Lloyd Howard, of Landrum; for Appellant
      Ricky Keith Harris, of Spartanburg; for Respondent.
        
      
    
  
     
    CURETON, J.: 
    Michael J. Sarratt was charged with public disorderly conduct.Â  Sarratt 
    waived his right to a jury trial and requested a bench trial.Â  The municipal 
    judge convicted Sarratt and ordered him to pay a fine of $112 or serve 20 
    days imprisonment.Â  Sarratt appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court 
    reversed the conviction.Â  The City of Landrum appeals. We reverse.
  FACTS
  Sarratt was arrested 
    for yelling profanities at Franklin Keith Hembree and his mother, June Hembree, 
    as they left the Landrum Municipal Court and walked across the municipal parking 
    lot.Â  Franklin testified Sarratt called him a crack head, loudly yelled profanities, 
    and called his mother a â€œbitch.â€Â  June testified Sarratt called her names 
    and used the â€œfâ€ word. 
  ISSUE
  Whether the circuit court erred in reversing 
    Sarrattâ€™s conviction, finding that although Sarratt used profanity in a public 
    place, profane language alone is insufficient to constitute a violation of 
    the public disorderly conduct statute.Â Â  
  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  â€œIn criminal appeals 
    from magistrate or municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de 
    novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate 
    exception.Â  In reviewing criminal cases, this court may review errors of law 
    only.â€ State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 457, 556 S.E.2d 691, 692 (Ct. 
    App. 2001) (internal citations omitted), cert. denied, Mar. 22, 2002 
    .
  LAW/ANALYSIS

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-530 provides: 
 
  Any person who shall 
    (a) be found on any highway or at any public place or public gathering in 
    a grossly intoxicated condition or otherwise conducting himself in a disorderly 
    or boisterous manner, (b) use obscene or profane language on any highway or 
    at any public place or gathering or in hearing distance of any schoolhouse 
    or church . . . shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction 
    shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars or be imprisoned for not 
    more than thirty days.
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-530 
    (1985). The circuit court found that â€œprofane language alone cannot constitute 
    a violation of the public disorderly conduct statute in light of the First 
    Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.â€ Rather, the circuit court 
    found that profane language must be accompanied by fighting words or other 
    behavior such as gross intoxication. 
  The First Amendment 
    prohibits laws that abridge the freedom of speech. U.S. Const. amend. I;Â  
    S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 2. There are, however, certain classes of speech that 
    are not afforded the protection of the First Amendment.Â  Chaplinsky v. 
    New Hampshire, 315 U.S. 568, 571-72 (1942). 
  One such class of 
    speech, fighting words, is defined as words that â€œby their very utterance 
    inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace.â€ Id. 
    at 572. Fighting words must be inherently likely to induce the ordinary person 
    to react violently. Cohen v. California, 403 U.S. 15, 20 (1971).Â Â  
    The fact that words are vulgar or offensive is not alone sufficient to classify 
    them as fighting words, thereby removing them from the protection provided 
    by the First Amendment. See Gooding v. Wilson, 405 U.S. 518, 
    527 (1972) (striking Georgia statute that, as construed, prohibited the use 
    of words that disgraced or insulted the listener, but did not constitute fighting 
    words); In re Louise C., 3 P.3d 1004, 1005-07 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1999) 
    (holding juvenileâ€™s use of â€œfâ€ word in argument with principal and another 
    student over whether student had cheated her out of money, although offensive 
    and unacceptable, did not constitute fighting words); Ware v. City & 
    County of Denver, 511 P.2d 475, 475-76 (Colo. 1973) (stating â€œone manâ€™s 
    vulgarity is anotherâ€™s lyricâ€ and holding defendantâ€™s statement â€œf--- youâ€ 
    during political speech at university not fighting words); Downs v. State, 
    366 A.2d 41, 42-46 (Md. 1976) (stating the defendantâ€™s use of profanity and 
    racial epithets in crowded, noisy restaurant in loud voice to fellow diners 
    not fighting words as not directed to anyone in particular; finding the use 
    of the â€œfâ€ word not punishable absent compelling reasons); City of Bismarck 
    v. Schoppert, 469 N.W.2d 808, 811 (N.D. 1991) (in finding â€œf--- youâ€ not 
    fighting words the court stated: â€œIt is . . . not a crime in this country 
    to be a boor, absent resort to fighting words.â€).Â  
  However, the determination 
    of whether profane words constitute fighting words depends upon the circumstances 
    surrounding their utterance. Lewis v. City of New Orleans, 415 U.S 
    130, 135 (1974) (Powell, J., concurring). Some of the factors to consider 
    in determining if profanity constitutes fighting words are the presence of 
    bystanders, the accompaniment of other aggressive behavior, and whether the 
    words are repeatedly uttered. See State v. Szymkiewicz, 678 
    A.2d 473, 475-79 (Conn. 1996) (finding fighting words where defendant repeatedly 
    cursed police officer and store detective and threatened store detective, 
    and uproar occurred in front of other customers who congregated to watch); 
    State v. Hammersly, 10 P.3d 1285, 1287-89 (Idaho 2000) (finding adult 
    in vehicle who yelled â€œshut your f---ing mouth, you b---- . . .â€ to 13 year 
    old friend of adultâ€™s daughter and two other preteens on street used fighting 
    words); State v. James M., 806 P.2d 1063, 1065-66 (N.M. Ct. App. 1990) 
    (holding minorâ€™s repeated yelling of â€œf--- youâ€ while flailing arms and pointing 
    at another individual on a public sidewalk as a small crowd congregated constituted 
    fighting words); In reÂ  S.J.N-K., 647 N.W.2d 707, 709-12 (S.D. 2002) 
    (stating the context in which the language is used must be considered; finding 
    minorâ€™s repeated use of â€œf--- youâ€ and middle finger gesture toward a school 
    principal and his family in a store parking lot, continuing while minor tailgated 
    principal as principal drove away, constituted fighting words).
  Whether a communication 
    constitutes fighting words also â€œdepends in large part on the addressee of 
    the communications.â€ Aviva O. Wertheimer, The First Amendment Distinction 
    Between Conduct and Content: A Conceptual Framework for Understanding Fighting 
    Words Jurisprudence, 63 Fordham L. Rev. 793, 813 (1994). In Cohen, 
    the defendantâ€™s display of the words â€œF--- the Draftâ€ on the back of his jacket 
    were determined not fighting words. 403 U.S. at 20-22. The court determined 
    â€œ[n]o individual actually or likely to be present could reasonably have regarded 
    the words on [Cohenâ€™s] jacket as a direct personal insult.â€ Id. at 
    20. The court explained that fighting words must be directed at someone in 
    particular. Id.
  In State v. Perkins, 
    our supreme court concluded a conviction under section 16-17-530 required 
    more than raised voices. 306 S.C. 353, 355, 412 S.E.2d 385, 386 (1991). Without 
    fighting words, the defendants in Perkins could not be convicted. Id. 
    Likewise, in State v. Pittman, this court stated if a defendantâ€™s â€œonly 
    disorderly behavior had been to use profanity, . . . he could not be arrested 
    for public disorderly conduct.â€ 342 S.C. 545, 548, 537 S.E.2d 563, 565 (Ct. 
    App. 2000). Both of these cases, however, involved law enforcement personnel 
    on the receiving end of the verbal abuse. See Perkins, 306 S.C. 
    at 354, 412 S.E.2d at 386 (sheriffâ€™s department employee); Pittman, 
    342 S.C. at 546, 537 S.E.2d at 564 (sheriffâ€™s department officer). The Perkins 
    court, relying on City of Houston v. Hill, noted the narrow application 
    of the fighting words exception in cases involving words addressed to a police 
    officer. Perkins, 306 S.C. at 354-55, 412 S.E.2d at 386. See 
    City of Houston v. Hill, 482 U.S. 451, 462 (1987) (limiting the fighting 
    words doctrine when the addressee, as a properly trained police officer, is 
    reasonably expected to exercise a higher degree of restraint than the average 
    citizen).
  More recently, this 
    court affirmed the trial courtâ€™s denial of a defendantâ€™s motion for a directed 
    verdict on his charge of disorderly conduct in violation of section 16-17-530. 
    State v. LaCoste, 347 S.C. 153, 163-64, 553 S.E.2d 464, 470 (Ct. App. 
    2001), cert. granted, Feb. 25, 2002. LaCoste threw up his arms in a 
    hostile manner and yelled obscenities at a police officer, insisting he would 
    not comply with the officerâ€™s demands.Â  After his arrest, LaCoste repeatedly 
    shouted obscenities, challenging the officer, and taunting the officer and 
    another officer regarding their lack of success in bringing him under control.Â  
    This court found there was sufficient evidence to enable the trial court to 
    deny LaCosteâ€™s motion for directed verdict. Id.
  Applying the fighting 
    words doctrine to the facts of this case, we agree with the magistrate and 
    conclude Sarrattâ€™s remarks, accompanied with the loud manner in which they 
    were spoken, constituted fighting words. We find Sarrattâ€™s language, especially 
    once he directed vulgarities at Franklinâ€™s mother, would incite an ordinary 
    person to violence.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order reversing Sarrattâ€™s 
    conviction is
  REVERSED.
  SHULER, J., concurs.
  HEARN, C.J., dissents 
    in separate opinion.
  HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  
    Because I disagree with the majority that the evidence supports the 
    finding that the statements uttered by Sarratt constitute fighting words, 
    I respectfully dissent. 
  The United States 
    Supreme Court has recognized the power of states to punish fighting words 
    under carefully drawn statutes which do not infringe upon protected forms 
    of speech.Â  Gooding v. Wilson, 405 U.S. 518, 523, 92 S.Ct. 1103, 1107 
    (1972).Â  The Court defines fighting words as â€œthose which by their very utterance 
    inflict injury or tend to incite an immediate breach of the peace.â€Â  Chaplinsky 
    v. New Hampshire, 315 U.S. 568, 572, 62 S.Ct. 766, 769 (1942).Â  The majority 
    correctly recognizes that the vulgarity or offensiveness of words is not by 
    itself sufficient to classify them as fighting words.Â  Wilson, 405 
    U.S. at 527, 92 S.Ct. at 1108.Â  However, the majority holds the language used 
    by Sarratt constituted fighting words finding that an ordinary person would 
    be incited to violence in light of the comments made by Sarratt, the tone 
    in which they were spoken, and the fact that vulgarities were directed at 
    Mrs. Hembree.Â  I believe the majority incorrectly reaches this conclusion 
    because there is no evidence in the record suggesting that Sarrattâ€™s comments 
    had any effect on the Hembrees other than to offend them.Â  Absent evidence 
    that Sarrattâ€™s statements tended to cause the Hembrees to react violently, 
    his words do not fall within the narrowly tailored exception to protected 
    speech set forth in Chaplinsky.
  Cases interpreting 
    Chaplinsky have made it clear that states may only prohibit speech 
    that has â€œa direct tendency to cause acts of violence by the person to 
    whom, individually, the remark is addressed.â€Â  Wilson, 405 U.S. 
    at 524, 92 S.Ct. at 1107 (emphasis added). See also Diehl v. State, 
    294 Md. 466, 474-75, 451 A.2d 115, 120 (1982) (stating fighting words are 
    those that â€œwould produce an uncontrollable impulse to violence . . .â€).Â  
    â€œIn effect, â€˜fightingâ€™ words have been recognized as having some social value 
    and are punishable now not on a â€˜per seâ€™ basis, but only when there is a likelihood 
    of imminent disturbance.â€Â  Downs v. State, 278 Md. 610, 615, 366 A.2d 
    41, 44 (1976) (citations omitted).Â  The mere use of profane or unpopular language 
    is not enough.Â  â€œLanguage likely to offend the sensibility of some listeners 
    is now fairly commonplace in many social gatherings as well as in public performances.â€Â  
    Eaton v. City of Tusla, 415 U.S. 697, 700, 94 S.Ct. 1228, 1231 (1974) 
    (Powell, J., concurring).Â  This is the very nature of free speech in our society.Â  
    The Supreme Court of Minnesota recognized the inherent difficulty in determining 
    the relative offensiveness of any particular expression.Â  The court stated,
  To begin with, curses, oaths, 
    expletives, . . . and the whole vocabulary of insults are not intended or 
    susceptible of literal interpretation.Â  They are expressions of annoyance 
    and hostility â€“ nothing more.Â  To attach greater significance to them is stupid, 
    ignorant, or naive.Â  Their significance is emotional, and it is not merely 
    immeasurable but variable.Â  
  City of Saint Paul v. Morris, 
    258 Minn. 467, 481, 104 N.W.2d 902, 910 (1960).Â  The court further noted that 
    the emotional quality of words varies from time to time, from region to region, 
    and as between social and cultural groups.Â  Id.
  Before one may be punished 
    for spoken words, there must be evidence that the abusive utterance itself 
    tended to incite an immediate breach of the peace.Â  See Downs, 
    278 Md. at 618, 366 A.2d at 46 (â€œAnd, even if someone were offended by [the 
    abusive statement], there was no evidence that any person was so aroused as 
    to respond in a violent manner.â€).Â  The State may not assume that provocative 
    expressions will incite such violence.Â  Rather, the State must carefully consider 
    the surrounding circumstances to determine â€œwhether the expression â€˜is directed 
    to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or 
    produce such action.â€™â€Â  Texas v. Johnson, 491 U.S. 397, 409, 109 S.Ct. 
    2533, 2542 (1989) (refusing to accept the Stateâ€™s argument that it need only 
    demonstrate a potential for breach of the peace). Certainly, words may convey 
    anger and frustration and yet not rise to a level such as to provoke a violent 
    reaction from the listener.Â  Lewis v. City of New Orleans, 415 U.S. 
    130, 135, 94 S.Ct. 970, 973 (1974) (Powell, J., concurring).Â  It is not enough 
    that the words merely arouse anger or resentment.Â  See Skelton v. 
    City of Birmingham, 342 So.2d 933, 937 (Ala. Crim. App. 1976).
  Here, the record shows only that a verbal exchange 
    occurred between the parties during which profanity was used.Â  Upon finding 
    Sarratt guilty, the magistrate stated, â€œOn the charge of public disorderly 
    conduct the way I understand the law . . . is that it was loud and boisterous, 
    there was cursing and all this . . . .â€Â  The magistrate makes no finding that 
    there was an imminent risk of violence resulting from Sarrattâ€™s statements 
    nor does the record suggest that any party involved was incited to react violently.Â  
    Moreover, the officer who arrested Sarratt did so based only on statements 
    given to him by the Hembrees, and he did not personally observe the altercation.Â  
    Accordingly, it is impossible for the officer to have assessed whether the 
    comments made by Sarratt, and circumstances under which they were made, were 
    so abusive towards the Hembrees that an immediate violent reaction was imminent.Â  
    See State v. James, 111 N.M. 473, 475, 806 P.2d 1063, 1065 (N.M. 
    Ct. App. 1990) (considering the fact that the arresting officer felt it necessary 
    to step between the arguing parties as evidence that a fight was likely to 
    ensue).Â Â  
  While this court may find it deplorable that Sarratt 
    directed abusive language towards Mr. Hembree and his mother, we must not 
    predicate a conviction for such conduct on our view of poor taste.Â  Instead, 
    the evidence must show that there was an imminent risk of violent reaction 
    to Sarrattâ€™s language.Â  In the absence of such evidence, Sarrattâ€™s expressions, 
    although profane in nature, are entitled to the protection granted by the 
    First Amendment to the Constitution.Â  Accordingly, I would affirm the circuit 
    courtâ€™s order reversing Sarrattâ€™s conviction.Â

THE STATE 
  OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social 
          Services,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Michael Meek and Angela Meek,        
          Defendants,
        Of WhomÂ  Angela Meek is the        
          Appellant.
In the Interest of:
Cynthia Meek ( DOB:Â  01-27-97) and
Kaitlyn Meek(12-08-99)
Minors under the age of 18. 
      
    
  


Appeal From 
  Lexington County
  Â Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3570
  Submitted October 8, 2002 â€“ Filed November 25, 2002

REVERSED 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Warren A. Kohn, 
          of Columbia; for Appellant
Montford Shuler Caughman, of Lexington; for 
  Respondent.
Ann Sharry Keisler, of Lexington; for Guardian Ad Litem
      
    
  


CONNOR, J.:Â  
  Angela Meek (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s decision to grant temporary 
  custody of her two minor daughters to the South Carolina Department of Social 
  Services (DSS).Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
On April 20, 2000, 
  the Lexington County Department of Social Services sought an ex parte order 
  granting it temporary emergency physical custody of the two daughters of Mother 
  and Michael Meek (Father).Â  The family court found that Father, while holding 
  a firearm, threatened to kill one of the children.Â  He then shot the firearm 
  in the home while fighting with Mother.Â  The family court also found Mother 
  was not willing to leave the home to protect herself or the two girls.Â  Accordingly, 
  the family court granted temporary emergency custody of the girls to DSS, finding 
  probable cause existed to believe there was imminent and substantial danger 
  to the life, health, or physical safety of the children.Â Â  
The probable cause hearing was held on April 24, 
  2000, and the family court made a finding that probable cause existed to take 
  the children into emergency protective custody.Â  The family court awarded custody 
  of the girls to DSS and ordered both Mother and Father to undergo psychological 
  testing.Â  The family court scheduled the merits hearing for May 24, 2000.Â  However, 
  the hearing was continued because no guardian ad litem had been appointed.Â  
  The order granting the continuance noted a waiver of the thirty-five-day statutory 
  period for the hearing.Â Â  
The court conducted 
  a merits hearing on August 2, 2000.Â  Mother appeared at the hearing with her 
  attorney, and the parties announced they had reached an agreement.Â  DSS indicated 
  that no agreement had been reached with Father, and a hearing would be held 
  regarding him sometime in the future.Â Â  
DSS announced to 
  the family court the agreement reached with Mother.Â  The parties agreed, among 
  other things, to a finding of physical neglect against Mother, the return of 
  custody of the two girls to Mother, and to continued monitoring by DSS. After 
  DSS stated the substance of the agreement on the record, the following exchange 
  took place:

[DSS]: Additionally, Your Honor, I will add that [Father], 
  who is accompanied by his attorney, has no objections to custody being returned 
  to Mrs. Meek.
[Court]: What about a restraint as to his contact?
[DSS]: He is in agreement with that, as well, Your Honor.
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
    . . .
[Court]: So heâ€™s not to have any contact with these children?
[Fatherâ€™s attorney]:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  No, sir.
           
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . .
[Court]: She understands she cannot have [Father] around 
  these children?
[Motherâ€™s attorney]:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Yes, she understands 
  that.

The family court approved the agreement.Â  However, 
  the August 29, 2000, written order (Motherâ€™s Order) failed to include the directive 
  that Mother keep the girls away from Father. 
Subsequently, Mother 
  informed the DSS case worker that she was pregnant with Fatherâ€™s child.Â  As 
  a result of contact between Father and the children, Mother signed a Voluntary 
  Placement Agreement, agreeing to give custody of the two girls to DSS for a 
  temporary period.Â  The agreement provided that DSS â€œmay petition the 
  Family Court for custody of my child(ren) at any time it deems such action necessary 
  or should continued placement be necessary beyond three (3) months.â€ The agreement 
  also provided that Mother could request the return of her children by informing 
  DSS of her request fifteen days before the date she wished them returned, but 
  DSS could petition the family court for an order preventing the return of the 
  children if DSS believed it was in the best interest of the children. 
The court finally 
  held the merits hearing regarding Father on March 5, 2001.Â  Neither Mother nor 
  her attorney appeared at the hearing.Â  In addressing Fatherâ€™s failure to stay 
  away from the children, one witness testified that Mother told DSS she was pregnant 
  by Father.Â  At the end of the hearing, the family court found that Father placed 
  the children in threat of harm of physical abuse and mental injury.Â  The court 
  further ordered that Father be entered in the child abuse registry.Â  Finally, 
  the family court granted DSSâ€™s request that the children remain in its custody.Â Â Â  

On March 27, 2001, 
  without a hearing, the family court issued an order amending Motherâ€™s Order.Â  
  The amended order added two provisions. One stated that Mother understood that 
  Father was not to have contact with the children, and another forbade Father 
  from contacting them.Â  It is not clear from the record when Mother was served 
  with a copy of this order.Â  The family court also issued an intervention order 
  regarding Father (Fatherâ€™s Order) on April 11, 2001, finding that Father placed 
  the children in threat of harm and that he should have no contact with the children.Â  
  Fatherâ€™s Order did not address Motherâ€™s conduct or custody of the children.Â  

On August 1, 2001, 
  Mother sent a written request for the return of her children pursuant to the 
  agreement she had signed with DSS.Â  On August 8, 2001, without a hearing, the 
  family court issued an amended Fatherâ€™s Order.Â  The amended Fatherâ€™s Order provided 
  that DSS should have continued temporary custody of the children because Mother 
  failed to comply with a previous court order.Â  Mother appeals from this order, 
  arguing: (1) the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction because DSSâ€™s 
  complaint did not include the required statutory notices; (2) the family court 
  lacked subject matter jurisdiction because the merits hearing was not held within 
  the statutory time constraints; and (3) Mother was unlawfully deprived of her 
  children and denied her constitutional due process rights because DSS failed 
  to give her notice or a hearing regarding the amended orders. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from 
  family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance 
  with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 
  332 S.C. 583, 591, 506 S.E.2d 1, 5 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. SUBJECT MATTER JURISDICTION
Mother argues the 
  family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the underlying proceedings 
  because: (1) the initial emergency removal complaint lacked adequate statutory 
  notices; and (2) her merits hearing was not held within the statutory time constraints.
A. COMPLAINT
Mother first claims 
  the family court was divested of subject matter jurisdiction because the complaint 
  for removal served on her did not contain the statutorily-required notices.Â  

The family court has 
  exclusive jurisdiction to hear matters concerning the abuse and neglect of children.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-736(A) (Supp. 2001). 
  [1] Â Â Â Â Â  
DSS served Mother 
  with a copy of the Complaint for the Ex Parte Order.Â  The complaint identified 
  the children, identified Mother and Father, and alleged there was probable cause 
  to believe there existed a substantial threat to the childrenâ€™s life, health, 
  or safety at the hands of Mother and Father.Â  The complaint sought the emergency 
  removal of the children from the parentsâ€™ custody.Â  
The General Assembly 
  has required that certain notices be placed in petitions for removal:

   (D)             
    Whether or not the petition for removal includes a petition for termination 
    of parental rights, the petition shall contain a notice informing the parents 
    of the potential effect of the hearing on their parental rights and a notice 
    to all interested parties that objections to the sufficiency of a placement 
    plan, if ordered, or of any recommendations for provisions in the plan or 
    court order must be raised at the hearing.Â  The notice must be printed in 
    boldface print or in all upper case letters and set off in a box. 
. . .
If the petition does not include a petition for termination 
  of parental rights, the notice shall state:Â  â€œAt this hearing the court may 
  order a treatment plan.Â  If you fail to comply with the plan, you could lose 
  your rights as a parent.â€

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-736(D) (Supp. 2001).Â  The complaint 
  served on Mother did not contain any of the notices outlined in the statute.Â  
  However, Mother did not complain about this failure before the family court.
Mother argues that 
  although the family court has exclusive subject matter jurisdiction to hear 
  cases involving child abuse and neglect, the court was divested of this jurisdiction 
  when DSS failed to include the necessary notices in the complaint.Â  It is clear 
  that DSS failed to include the necessary notices.Â  However, nothing in the statute 
  purports to divest the family court of subject matter jurisdiction where the 
  notice requirements are not met by DSS.
Â 
â€œSubject matter jurisdiction 
  is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to 
  which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 
  139, 150, 526 S.E.2d 222, 227 (2000).Â  DSSâ€™s failure to include the appropriate 
  notices in the complaint for removal may have violated certain due process rights 
  of Mother, but the failure did not deprive the family court of subject matter 
  jurisdiction over the emergency protective removal proceedings concerning Motherâ€™s 
  children.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 
  S.C. 129, 134-35, 538 S.E.2d 285, 288 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œThe law provides the 
  family court has exclusive jurisdiction over all proceedings involving the termination 
  of parental rights.Â  We are aware of no provision divesting the court of that 
  jurisdiction based on alleged improper removal of a child.â€) (internal citation 
  omitted).
Moreover, since 
  the failure of DSS to include the necessary notices in the complaint for removal 
  does not involve a question of subject matter jurisdiction, this issue should 
  have been raised to the family court.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 
  330 S.C. 71, 497 S.E.2d 731 (1998) (stating an issue cannot be raised for the 
  first time on appeal).
B. TIME LIMITS
Mother next argues 
  the family court was divested of subject matter jurisdiction to hear this matter 
  because the family court failed to hold the merits hearing within the statutorily 
  required time limits.Â  
DSS brought the 
  emergency action to remove the girls from Motherâ€™s custody on April 20, 2000.Â  
  The family court held a probable cause hearing on April 24, 2000, and scheduled 
  the merits hearing for May 24, 2000.Â  On this date, DSS notified the family 
  court that a guardian ad litem had not been appointed.Â  The family court issued 
  an order continuing the matter for this reason.Â  The order specified that the 
  thirty-five-day time limit had been waived.Â  Nothing in the record indicates 
  whether Mother appeared before the family court on May 24, 2000, or whether 
  she agreed to waive the thirty-five-day time limit.Â  Motherâ€™s merits hearing 
  was held on August 2, 2000.Â  Mother entered into an agreement with DSS at the 
  hearing and did not object to the timing of the hearing.Â  
The General Assembly 
  has provided strict timelines for hearings on the removal of children.Â  â€œThe 
  family court shall schedule a probable cause hearing to be held within seventy-two 
  hours of the time the child was taken into emergency protective custody.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-610(M) (Supp. 2001).Â  Further, the merits hearing â€œto determine 
  whether removal of custody is needed, pursuant to Section 20-7-736, must be 
  held within thirty-five days of the date of receipt of the removal petition.â€Â  
  Id.Â  A continuance may be granted for exceptional circumstances, however, 
  â€œthe hearing on the merits must be completed within sixty-five days following 
  receipt of the removal petitionâ€ if a continuance is granted.Â  Id.Â  Section 
  20-7-736 also provides that the family court shall â€œschedule a hearing to be 
  held within thirty-five daysâ€ of the date of receipt of the removal petition.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-736(E) (Supp. 2001).
In reviewing the 
  time limits outlined by statute, our Supreme Court has stated that the family 
  court â€œmust strictly comply with this schedule of hearings.Â  The family court 
  should order custody be returned to the childâ€™s parent or legal guardian if 
  the hearings are not held within ten days after the statutory time limits.â€Â  
  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 289, 513 S.E.2d 358, 363 (1999).Â  
More recently, 
  in South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Gamble, 337 S.C. 428, 523 S.E.2d 
  477 (Ct. App. 1999), this Court reviewed the time limits described in the removal 
  statutes.Â  Gambleâ€™s minor child was removed from her home and placed into emergency 
  protective custody after a report of suspected abuse.Â  The family court scheduled 
  the merits hearing for September 15, thirty-two days after the petition for 
  removal was filed.Â  However, on the day of the scheduled merits hearing, the 
  family court determined the matter could not be concluded during the allotted 
  time and ordered that the matter be rescheduled.Â  Thereafter, Gamble requested 
  and received an order allowing discovery.Â  The merits hearing was held on November 
  5, but was not concluded.Â  Gamble then moved to vacate the order granting custody 
  to DSS because the merits hearing was not held within thirty-five days of the 
  receipt of the removal petition.Â  The family court granted Gambleâ€™s motion to 
  dismiss for failure to prosecute, and DSS appealed.Â  This Court compared the 
  requirement from section 20-7-610(M) that the merits hearing â€œmust be heldâ€ 
  within thirty-five days of receipt of the removal petition with the requirement 
  found in section 20-7-736(E) that the family court â€œshall schedule a hearing 
  to be held within thirty-five daysâ€ of receipt of the petition for removal.Â  
  Reading the two statutes together, this Court held:

[T]he plain language of the statute indicates that a merits 
  hearing must be scheduled to be held within thirty-five days of receipt 
  of the removal petition.Â  The statute does not indicate that the hearing must 
  be completed within the thirty-five day period.Â  Therefore the requirement 
  that a hearing on the merits actually come to a conclusion within thirty-five 
  days of the removal petition should not be read into the statute.

Gamble, 337 S.C. at 432, 523 S.E.2d at 479.Â  
Mother argues the family 
  court lost subject matter jurisdiction as a result of the failure to abide by 
  the time limits mandated by statute.Â  As previously discussed, the family court 
  is given exclusive jurisdiction over matters concerning the abuse and neglect 
  of children.Â  Although the statutes outlining the time limits for the merits 
  hearing indicate that a hearing should at least have been scheduled within thirty-five 
  days, and completed within sixty-five days, of the receipt of the removal petition, 
  nothing purports to remove jurisdiction over the abuse and neglect case if the 
  hearing is not held within these time limits.Â  The failure to complete the merits 
  hearing within sixty-five days of receipt of the petition for removal did not 
  deprive the family court of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  As in Gamble, 
  it is clear the family court complied with the statutes considering it originally 
  scheduled the merits hearing to be held within thirty-five days of the receipt 
  of the removal petition. [2] Â  
  Moreover, the remedy for the failure to complete the hearing within the specified 
  time limits was for Mother to petition for the return of her children or move 
  to vacate the order granting custody to DSS.Â  Mother did not pursue either action 
  and did not raise this issue to the family court. 
  [3] Â  
Â Â  
II. DUE PROCESS VIOLATIONS
Mother argues her 
  due process rights were violated and she was unlawfully deprived of custody 
  of her children when the family court entered an amended order without giving 
  her notice or opportunity to be heard.Â  
â€œDue process is 
  a flexible concept, and the requirements of due process in a particular case 
  are dependent upon the importance of the interest involved and the circumstances 
  under which the deprivation may occur.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. 
  v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997). Â â€œThe fundamental 
  requirement of due process is the opportunity to be heard at a meaningful time 
  and in a meaningful manner.â€Â  Id.Â  Litigants should be placed on notice 
  of the issues that the court is to consider in order to comply with due process.Â  
  Murdock v. Murdock, 338 S.C. 322, 333, 526 S.E.2d 241, 248 (Ct. App. 
  1999) (finding family court erred in addressing issue of debt allocation where 
  the husband did not receive notice that the issue would be addressed at the 
  hearing on a rule to show cause for failure to pay child support).Â  
The family court determined 
  the merits of the abuse allegations against Mother at the August 2, 2000, hearing.Â  
  The parties clearly indicated that the agreement reached at the hearing dealt 
  only with Mother and that the merits of the abuse allegations against Father 
  would be dealt with at a later hearing.Â  The Voluntary Placement Agreement (VPA), 
  dated January 31, 2001, between DSS and Mother indicated that DSS would petition 
  the family court if it believed it necessary to seek further determinations 
  regarding custody of the children.Â  This indicates a formal process, with notice 
  to interested parties, would be undertaken before a determination would be made 
  on the custody of the children.Â  
However, DSS did not 
  apprise Mother that it would request a finding against her or request the family 
  court for continued custody of the children at Fatherâ€™s merits hearing on March 
  5, 2001.Â  The family court issued Fatherâ€™s Order on April 11, 2001.Â  This order 
  included no findings concerning Mother or custody of the children.Â  After Mother 
  followed the procedure outlined in the VPA to request custody of her children, 
  Fatherâ€™s Order was amended to continue custody with DSS based on Motherâ€™s violation 
  of a previous court order. [4] Â  
  DSS argues the family court was merely correcting â€œclerical errorsâ€ by adding 
  information discussed at Fatherâ€™s hearing but not included in the order.Â  There 
  is no merit to this argument where the â€œcorrectionâ€ goes to the very heart of 
  the violation of Motherâ€™s fundamental right to due process.Â  
Motherâ€™s interest in the custody of her children 
  is extraordinarily significant.Â  Motherâ€™s fundamental right to due process entitled 
  her to notice that DSS intended to petition the family court for custody of 
  the children at Fatherâ€™s hearing.Â  Murdock, 338 S.C. at 333, 526 S.E.2d 
  at 248.Â  Moreover, DSS failed to follow its own procedures outlined in the VPA.Â  
  Pursuant to the VPA, DSS should have petitioned the family court to prevent 
  the return of the children upon Motherâ€™s request.Â  Because DSS failed to follow 
  the procedures outlined in the VPA, and failed to give Mother notice and an 
  opportunity to be heard at Fatherâ€™s merits hearing, we reverse that portion 
  of the amended Fatherâ€™s Order which grants custody of the children to DSS based 
  upon Motherâ€™s conduct.Â  We remand this matter to the family court for a full 
  hearing to determine whether DSS is entitled to custody of the children beyond 
  the time limits agreed upon by the parties in the VPA.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, 
  the portion of the amended Fatherâ€™s Order addressing custody of the children 
  and Motherâ€™s conduct is REVERSED and REMANDED for proceedings 
  consistent with this opinion.Â  A hearing on these issues shall be held immediately. 

REVERSED AND 
  REMANDED. 

ANDERSON and 
  STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â  Although we recognize this case arose in April 2000, we cite to 
    the most current version of the Code throughout this opinion given no substantive 
    amendments have been made to the pertinent statutes since this litigation 
    began.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  However, as noted, the merits hearing was not completed within 
    sixty-five days.Â  Thus, it is not clear that the family court complied with 
    the statute in this regard.Â  We make no ruling on whether the failure to complete 
    the hearing within this time limit violated the statute in this case.Â  Our 
    ruling is limited to whether the time-limit discrepancies deprived the family 
    court of subject matter jurisdiction.

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Because the family courtâ€™s compliance with the statutory time limits 
    is not an issue of subject matter jurisdiction, Mother should have objected 
    to the continuance to preserve the issue for appellate review.Â  Joubert 
    v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 341 S.C. 176, 534 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. 
    App. 2000).Â Â  

 
   
    [4] Â Â  Presumably, Mother violated the amended Motherâ€™s Order prohibiting 
    contact between Father and the children.Â  DSS was aware of this violation 
    at the time the parties executed the VPA.Â  Thus, it is questionable why DSS 
    sought an amended Fatherâ€™s Order continuing custody of the children with DSS 
    based on this violation.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In 
  The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
William Wade Pitts,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Jackson National Life Insurance
        Company,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3571
Heard September 11, 2002 â€“ Filed November 25, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Paul J. Doolittle, of Mt. Pleasant; and Ronald R. Parry, 
  of Covington, KY, for appellant.
David L. Freeman and J. Theodore Gentry, of Greenville; 
  and Joel S. Feldman, of Chicago, IL, for respondent.
      
    
  


CONNOR, J.:Â  
  This appeal arises out of Jackson National Life Insurance Companyâ€™s sale of 
  preferred and non-preferred whole life insurance polices.Â  Southland Container 
  Corporation originally brought this class action suit against Jackson National, 
  alleging several causes of action including breach of fiduciary duty/constructive 
  fraud; fraudulent concealment and non-disclosure; and unjust enrichment and 
  imposition of a constructive trust.Â  William Wade Pitts was later substituted 
  as named plaintiff.Â  The circuit court granted Jackson Nationalâ€™s motion to 
  dismiss the breach of fiduciary duty and constructive fraud causes of action; 
  granted Jackson Nationalâ€™s summary judgment motion as to the fraudulent concealment 
  claim; and denied Pittsâ€™s motion for summary judgment as to his claim for unjust 
  enrichment.Â  Pitts appeals.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS/PROCEDURAL 
  HISTORY
In 1990, Southland 
  Container Corporation (Southland) purchased â€œkey-manâ€ life insurance on David 
  Katt, its president, from Jackson National.Â  Southland purchased an Ultimate 
  II policy on Katt.Â  Katt allegedly would have qualified for a less expensive 
  Preferred Ultimate II policy, but Southland was not aware of this policy and 
  was not informed of it by Jackson Nationalâ€™s agent. Â In a suit filed 
  December 1, 1995, Southland Container alleged Jackson National sold it the Ultimate 
  II policy when it actually qualified for the Preferred Ultimate II policy.Â  
  The complaint alleged five causes of action:Â  violation of unfair trade practices 
  act; breach of fiduciary duty/constructive fraud; negligence; fraudulent concealment 
  and non-disclosure; and unjust enrichment and imposition of a constructive trust.Â Â Â Â  
  
Southland moved 
  for class certification, and a class of South Carolina Jackson National policyholders 
  who purchased non-preferred Ultimate policies, but would have been qualified 
  to purchase preferred policies, was conditionally certified.Â  William Wade Pitts 
  was substituted as named plaintiff and class representative in place of Southland 
  Container when it became apparent that Katt could not devote the necessary time 
  to the litigation.Â Â  
From 1985 to 1995, 
  Jackson National offered two versions of its whole life insurance policy, the 
  Ultimate I and Ultimate II.Â  Jackson National also offered separate, but corresponding 
  preferred policies, the Preferred Ultimate I and Preferred Ultimate II.Â  The 
  preferred policies had stricter underwriting standards, charged lower premiums, 
  and paid the broker a lower commission than the standard policies of equal face 
  amounts.Â  Non-preferred policies were available to all insurance applicants, 
  while preferred polices were available to â€œa more restrictive pool of insureds 
  who [had] above average health, good life expectancy, no recent history of smoking 
  and qualif[ied] under factors such as age and amount of insurance.â€Â  Jackson 
  Nationalâ€™s underwriting department assessed the insurability of an applicant 
  based on the policy requested.Â  Thus, if the applicant qualified for the policy 
  in the application, Jackson National would issue that policy without further 
  investigation into whether the applicant qualified for a different policy.Â  
  If the applicant did not qualify for the applied-for policy, Jackson National 
  would advise if the applicant qualified for a different policy.Â  
Pitts purchased 
  his insurance through an independent insurance agent, Bruce Loring, with whom 
  he had no previous relationship. Â Pitts purchased an Ultimate II policy 
  for his daughter and a Preferred Ultimate II policy for himself.Â  Although Pittsâ€™s 
  daughter may have qualified for a preferred policy, Loring testified he chose 
  to seek a non-preferred policy for her because he believed she would not qualify 
  for the preferred policy because of her weight.Â  Jackson National issued both 
  policies as applied for, and the policies were accepted and paid for by Pitts.Â  
  The amended complaint alleged Pittsâ€™s daughter qualified for the Preferred Ultimate 
  II policy but was issued an Ultimate II policy instead, resulting in damages 
  to Pitts. Â Â Â 
Jackson National 
  filed a motion to dismiss all five causes of action.Â  The circuit court dismissed 
  the causes of action for unfair trade practices, breach of fiduciary duty, and 
  negligence.Â  Both parties moved for reconsideration, and the circuit court also 
  dismissed the constructive fraud claim. Â 
Following discovery, 
  Jackson National moved for summary judgment on the fraudulent concealment claim.Â  
  Pitts moved for summary judgment on the equitable claim of unjust enrichment.Â  
  The circuit court granted Jackson Nationalâ€™s motion and denied Pittsâ€™s motion.Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Pitts appeals, 
  arguing the circuit court erred in dismissing the claims for breach of fiduciary 
  duty and constructive fraud, in granting Jackson Nationalâ€™s motion for summary 
  judgment on the fraudulent concealment claim, and in denying his motion for 
  summary judgment on the unjust enrichment claim.Â Â Â  
DISCUSSION
Pitts argues the 
  circuit court erred in granting Jackson Nationalâ€™s motions to dismiss the claims 
  for breach of fiduciary duty and constructive fraud.Â  Jackson Nationalâ€™s motions 
  to dismiss were made pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  â€œUnder Rule 12(b)(6), 
  SCRCP, a defendant may make a motion to dismiss based on a failure to state 
  facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.â€Â  Baird v. Charleston County, 
  333 S.C. 519, 527, 511 S.E.2d 69, 73 (1999).Â  â€œGenerally, in considering a 12(b)(6) 
  motion, the trial court must base its ruling solely upon allegations set forth 
  on the face of the complaint.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œA Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss 
  for failure to state a cause of action must be resolved by the trial judge based 
  solely on the allegations established in the complaint.â€ Berry v. McLeod, 
  328 S.C. 435, 441, 492 S.E.2d 794, 797 (Ct. App. 1997). 
In deciding upon 
  Jackson Nationalâ€™s motions to dismiss, the circuit court considered matters 
  outside the pleadings.Â  Numerous exhibits were submitted in the memorandum in 
  opposition to the motion to dismiss, including a copy of the life insurance 
  policy and several tables of policy values.Â  â€œIf on a motion under 12(b)(6) 
  matters outside the pleadings are presented and not excluded, the motion shall 
  be treated as one for summary judgment.â€ McDonnell v. Consol. Sch. Dist. 
  of Aiken, 315 S.C. 487, 489 n.2, 445 S.E.2d 638, 639 n.2 (1994); see 
  Berry, 328 S.C. at 441, 492 S.E.2d at 798 (finding where trial court 
  decided Rule 12(b)(6) motion based on matters outside the pleadings, the court 
  converted the motion to dismiss into a summary judgment motion pursuant to Rule 
  56, SCRCP). 
â€œ[Rule 12(b)(6)] 
  specifically provides for conversion, provided the parties, upon compliance 
  with the notice provisions of Rule 56, are afforded a reasonable opportunity 
  to introduce evidentiary matters.â€ Johnson v. Dailey, 318 S.C. 318, 321, 
  457 S.E.2d 613, 615 (1995).Â  The pertinent portion of Rule 12(b) allowing conversion 
  provides: 

If, on a motion asserting the defense numbered (6) to dismiss 
  for failure of the pleading to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause 
  of action, matters outside the pleading are presented to and not excluded by 
  the Court, the motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed 
  of as provided in Rule 56, and all parties shall be given reasonable opportunity 
  to present all material pertinent to such a motion by Rule 56.

The memorandum 
  containing the outside materials was dated and filed on May 28, 1996.Â  The order 
  was dated November 25, 1996 and filed November 26, 1996. Â Because the 
  judge issued the order six months after the memorandum was filed, there was 
  ample opportunity for the parties to introduce additional evidentiary matters 
  if they desired.Â  Thus, the circuit court implicitly converted the motions to 
  dismiss into summary judgment motions under the provisions of Rule 12(b), SCRCP.Â  
  As such, the procedural posture from which we review these claims is that of 
  summary judgment.
Summary judgment 
  is proper when it is clear there is no genuine issue as to any material fact 
  and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  West v. 
  Gladney, 341 S.C. 127, 132, 533 S.E.2d 334, 336 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€œSummary 
  judgment can be granted when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on 
  which reasonable minds cannot differ.â€Â  Byerly v. Connor, 307 S.C. 441, 
  445, 415 S.E.2d 796, 799 (1992).
â€œIn reviewing the 
  grant of a summary judgment motion, this Court applies the same standard which 
  governs the trial court.â€ Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 
  319, 321 (2001).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, 
  the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light 
  most favorable to the non-moving party.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œOn appeal from an order 
  granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, 
  conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most 
  favorable to the non-moving party below.â€Â  Id.  
I.Â  Breach of Fiduciary Duty
Pitts [1]  argues the circuit court erred in 
  dismissing the claim for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  Pitts specifically asserts 
  â€œJackson National had a fiduciary duty to provide complete and truthful information 
  to Appellant and Class members when selling insurance policies to them, and 
  it breached that duty when it failed to make full disclosure with respect to 
  the type of policies available, the charges, commissions, mortality costs and 
  other expenses associated with those policies . . . .â€Â Â Â Â  
Pitts, however, 
  conceded at oral argument the relationship in this case cannot be considered 
  a â€œpureâ€ fiduciary relationship.Â  Instead, he contends the relationship is based 
  on the unique circumstances of the sale of insurance, which creates a heightened 
  duty, particularly the duty of good faith and fair dealing.
â€œA confidential 
  or fiduciary relationship exists when one imposes a special confidence in another, 
  so that the latter, in equity and good conscience, is bound to act in good faith 
  and with due regard to the interests of the one imposing the confidence.â€Â  Island 
  Car Wash, Inc. v. Norris, 292 S.C. 595, 599, 358 S.E.2d 150, 152 (Ct. App. 
  1987).Â Â Â  A relationship must be more than casual to equal a fiduciary relationship.

  5, 437 S.E.2d 6, 8 (1993) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to 
  ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€).Â  Additionally, Pitts 
  presented no evidence of discrimination in contracting for insurance that would 
  constitute a violation of this statute.Â  All individuals were treated the same 
  and received the policy they applied for if they qualified. See Smith v. Liberty 
  Mut. Ins. Co., 313 S.C. 236, 437 S.E.2d 142 (Ct. App. 1993) (recognizing section 
  38-55-50 relates to discrimination in contracting for insurance).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing 
  reasons, the decision of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and 
  STILWELL, JJ., concur.

     [1] Â  At the time of the motions to dismiss, Southland Container 
    was the named plaintiff.Â  Pitts was substituted on October 1, 1999, after 
    the motions to dismiss were heard and ruled upon. Â For continuity, 
    Pitts will be discussed as if he were the named plaintiff throughout all of 
    the proceedings in the circuit court, including the motions to dismiss.
