THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John H. Simmons,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3572
Heard November 7, 2002 â€“ Filed November 
  25, 2002

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda H. Haile, 
  of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Charles M. Condon, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; 
  and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  John H. Simmons was convicted 
  of first degree burglary and petit larceny.Â  He was sentenced to life without 
  the possibility of parole.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 4, 1999, at approximately 2:15 a.m., Shirley 
  Ann Thompson was in bed when she heard her door beep.Â  Thompson had aÂ  burglar 
  alarm system in her home on Liberty Street, but she did not have the alarm activated 
  that evening.Â  Even without the alarm activated, the system would beep whenever 
  a door in Thompsonâ€™s home was opened.Â  Initially, Thompson assumed it was her 
  son, but she soon discovered the man she saw carrying a light in her hallway 
  was not her son.Â  Thompson watched the figure walk down the hallway and grab 
  her purse from the doorknob of her bedroom door, pulling the bedroom door closed 
  in the process.Â  Thompson grabbed her gun, chased the man out of her house, 
  and shot toward him as he was fleeing down Liberty Street in the direction of 
  the car wash.Â  Thompson then called the police to report the burglary (Thompson 
  burglary).Â  She described the man as a dark-skinned black male wearing a black 
  shirt with white writing on the back.
On that same morning, Douglas Brooks was watching television 
  at his home near the intersection of Liberty and Magrath Streets, which was 
  a block and a half away from Thompsonâ€™s home.Â  Sometime after 2:00 a.m., Brooks 
  heard a loud noise coming from his back door which sounded like someone was 
  trying to kick the door in.Â  Brooks investigated the noise and saw someone jump 
  off of his back porch.Â  Brooks chased the man until he ran across Colonial Drive.Â  
  Brooks stopped pursuing the suspect, and turned around to see a patrol car responding 
  to the call at Thompsonâ€™s house.Â  Brooks flagged the officer down, informed 
  him of the incident at his home, and described the suspect as wearing dark clothing.
As Officer Robert Lee Gibson was driving to Thompsonâ€™s house in response to 
  her call to 911, he saw a man in dark clothing run across Colonial Drive as 
  he approached Liberty Street.Â  Gibson informed another officer that he saw the 
  suspect running down Colonial Drive.Â  Police circled the area to find the suspect.Â  
  Minutes later, the police located Simmons, who was hiding in some nearby bushes.Â  
  He was wearing a black t-shirt with white writing on it.Â  In the bushes, police 
  found some clothing and other items Brooks had stored in his outside shed.Â  
  Simmons had abrasions on his head.Â  An ambulance was called to examine Simmonsâ€™ 
  wounds.
Thompson was taken to the scene, where she identified Simmons as the figure 
  she had seen in her home.Â  Although Thompsonâ€™s purse was not immediately located, 
  it was discovered the next morning across the street from the car wash near 
  a daycare center.Â  Because Brooks only viewed the suspect from the rear, he 
  was unable to identify Simmons as the man who ran from his back porch. 
Edward Anderson, a co-worker of Simmons, testified at 
  trial.Â  He stated that he and Simmons were working at the Cotton Club the evening 
  of October 3, 1999.Â  That night, Simmons was wearing the clubâ€™s uniform, a black 
  t-shirt with â€œCotton Clubâ€ written on the back in white writing, along with 
  black pants and suspenders.Â  Anderson declared that he and Simmons left the 
  club when it closed at midnight on October 4, 1999.Â  The two men went to Daveâ€™s 
  Lounge, where they drank several alcoholic beverages.Â  On previous occasions, 
  Anderson had driven Simmons home after work.Â  Their route took them down Beltline 
  Boulevard.Â  After the two left Daveâ€™s around 2:00 a.m., an intoxicated Simmons 
  directed Anderson to vary from their usual route by letting him out of the car 
  near Beltline Boulevard and Colonial Drive, without explanation.Â  Anderson let 
  Simmons out of the car on Colonial Drive.Â  Anderson then continued home.
Peter Banco, an officer with the Columbia police department, 
  responded to Thompsonâ€™s house on the morning of the burglary.Â  He took a statement 
  from Thompson at 4:05 a.m.Â  He later returned to his office where he was able 
  to speak with Simmons, who was already in custody.Â  Banco gave Simmons his Miranda 
  warnings.Â  Simmons indicated he understood his rights.Â  Simmons smelled of alcohol 
  but he did not appear drunk to Banco.Â  When Banco asked Simmons whether he could 
  have attempted to break into Thompsonâ€™s and Brooksâ€™ homes, Simmons replied that 
  he did not â€œknow whatâ€™s going on.â€Â  The interview ended.
Simmons testified in his own defense at trial.Â  He stated 
  that the evening of the incident, he was wearing his black Cotton Club shirt 
  with black tuxedo pants.Â  He started drinking alcoholic beverages at about 4:00 
  p.m. while he was preparing dinner at home.Â  Simmons had a few more drinks at 
  the Cotton Club.Â  He and Anderson left the Cotton Club at midnight and went 
  to Daveâ€™s Lounge, where he imbibed three or four alcoholic drinks. According 
  to Simmons, when he and Anderson left Daveâ€™s Lounge sometime between 1:00 and 
  2:00 a.m., Simmons was not intoxicated.Â  Simmons claimed he asked Anderson to 
  stop the car because he began to feel nauseous from all the alcohol he drank 
  that day and he wanted to get out and walk.Â  Simmons declared that he put on 
  his earphones to his radio and began to walk along the edge of the road, when 
  he thought he heard someone come up behind him.Â  Simmons stated that, when he 
  turned around to see a police patrol car behind him, he was struck by the patrol 
  car.Â  Simmons said he blacked out at that point, and his next memory was of 
  waking up when medical personnel were working on him.Â  Simmons denied breaking 
  into Thompsonâ€™s residence or attempting to break into Brooksâ€™ home.Â  He further 
  denied being in the bushes that morning.Â  Simmons maintained the abrasion on 
  his face that morning was the result of being hit by the patrol car.
ISSUES

    I.                   
    Did the Circuit Court err in denying Simmonsâ€™ motion to sever?
    II.                
    Did the Circuit Court err in denying Simmonsâ€™ motion for a mistrial after 
    directed verdicts of acquittal were issued on the burglary and petit larceny 
    charges from the Brooks burglary?
    III.             
    Did the Circuit Court err in allowing the use of Simmonsâ€™ prior burglary and 
    housebreaking convictions to prove an element of first degree burglary?

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â 
SEVERANCE/JOINDER
Simmons argues the trial judge erred in failing to sever the two 
  burglary charges against him for trial.Â  We disagree.
Prior to trial, Simmons moved to sever the charges against him.Â  
  Simmons contended the victims in the Thompson and Brooks burglaries were different, 
  the witnesses were different, and the acts alleged were different. Simmons asserted 
  he would be prejudiced if the jury heard about both the Thompson and the Brooks 
  burglaries because the evidence was stronger in the Thompson matter and would 
  influence the jury on the Brooks matter.Â  The trial judge noted that the matter 
  was within his discretion, and the trial proceeded on both sets of charges.
A motion for severance is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  
  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996); McCrary v. State, 
  249 S.C. 14, 152 S.E.2d 235 (1967); State v. Carter, 324 S.C. 383, 478 
  S.E.2d 86 (Ct. App. 1996); State v. Anderson, 318 S.C. 395, 458 S.E.2d 
  56 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  The courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal absent 
  an abuse of that discretion.Â  Tucker, 324 S.C. at 164, 478 S.E.2d at 
  265; State v. Prince, 316 S.C. 57, 447 S.E.2d 177 (1993); State v. 
  Deal, 319 S.C. 49, 459 S.E.2d 93 (Ct. App. 1995); see also State 
  v. Harris, Op. No. 25535 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Oct. 14, 2002) (Shearouse 
  Adv. Sh. No. 34 at 32) (stating a motion for severance is addressed to trial 
  court and should not be disturbed unless abuse of discretion is shown).
Where the offenses charged in separate indictments are of 
  the same general nature involving connected transactions closely related in 
  kind, place and character, the trial judge has the power, in his discretion, 
  to order the indictments tried together if the defendantâ€™s substantive rights 
  would not be prejudiced. Â State v. Smith, 322 S.C. 107, 470 S.E.2d 364 
  (1996); State v. Williams, 263 S.C. 290, 210 S.E.2d 298 (1974); State 
  v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 479 S.E.2d 517 (Ct. App. 1996); see also 
  State v. Sullivan, 277 S.C. 35, 282 S.E.2d 838 (1981) (where offenses 
  charged in separate indictments are of same general nature, involving connected 
  transactions closely related in kind, place and character, trial judge has authority, 
  in his discretion, to order indictments tried together over objection of defendant 
  absent showing that defendantâ€™s substantive rights were violated); McCrary 
  v. State, 249 S.C. 14, 36, 152 S.E.2d 235, 246 (1967) (stating â€œ[t]he two 
  offenses were of the same general nature, involving connected transactions closely 
  related in time, place and character; and the trial judge had power, in his 
  discretion, to order them tried together over objection by the defendant in 
  the absence of a showing that the latterâ€™s substantive rights would have been 
  thereby prejudiced.â€).Â  Offenses are considered to be of the same general nature 
  where they are interconnected.Â  Jones, 325 S.C. at 315, 479 S.E.2d at 
  519.
Conversely, offenses which are of the same nature, but which 
  do not arise out of a single chain of circumstances and are not provable by 
  the same evidence may not properly be tried together.Â  See, e.g., 
  State v. Middleton, 288 S.C. 21, 339 S.E.2d 692 (1986) (holding although 
  prison escapee committed two murders within a few miles of each other and attempted 
  an armed robbery, the trial judge erred in consolidating the charges for one 
  trial where the crimes did not arise out of a single chain of circumstances 
  and they required different evidence); State v. Tate, 286 S.C. 462, 334 
  S.E.2d 289 (Ct. App. 1985) (finding that joint trial on identical but unrelated 
  forgeries violated defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial).Â  Cf. State 
  v. Woomer, 276 S.C. 258, 277 S.E.2d 696 (1981) (proper to try together all 
  crimes arising from a single uninterrupted crime spree).
Further, joinder of offenses in one trial is â€œproper if the offenses (1) are 
  of the same general nature or character and spring from the same series of transactions, 
  (2) are committed by the same offender, and (3) require the same or similar 
  proof.â€Â  State v. Carter, 324 S.C. 383, 386, 478 S.E.2d 86, 88 (Ct. App. 
  1996) (citing City of Greenville v. Chapman, 210 S.C. 157, 41 S.E.2d 
  865 (1947)); see also State v. Harris, Op. No. 25535 (S.C. 
  Sup. Ct. filed Oct. 14, 2002) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 34 at 32) (â€œCharges can 
  be joined in the same indictment and tried together where they (1) arise out 
  of a single chain of circumstances, (2) are proved by the same evidence, (3) 
  are of the same general nature, and (4) no real right of the defendant has been 
  prejudiced.â€).
In the instant case, the joinder of the separate burglary offenses 
  was proper.Â  The break-in at Thompsonâ€™s house was very close in time and proximity 
  to the attempted break-in at Brooksâ€™ home.Â  Although Brooks could not identify 
  the physical characteristics of the man who attempted to break into his home, 
  both Brooks and Thompson similarly described the suspect as wearing dark clothing.Â  
  Simmons was found after Brooks chased him and directed police to Simmonsâ€™ location.Â  
  Despite the fact that Simmons was granted a directed verdict in the Brooks matter, 
  both the indictments in the Brooks matter and the Thompson matter arose out 
  of a single chain of events, were of the same nature, and were proved by the 
  same evidence and witnesses.Â  We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in refusing to sever the indictments.
II.Â  RES GESTAE
Furthermore, the evidence of the Brooks burglary was necessary for a full presentation 
  of the case without fragmentation.Â  In State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 
  470 S.E.2d 366 (1996), our Supreme Court explained:

One of the accepted bases for the admissibility of evidence 
  of other crimes arises when such evidence â€œfurnishes part of the context of 
  the crimeâ€ or is necessary to a â€œfull presentationâ€ of the case, or is so intimately 
  connected with and explanatory of the crime charged against the defendant and 
  is so much a part of the setting of the case and its â€œenvironmentâ€ that its 
  proof is appropriate in order â€œto complete the story of the crime on trial by 
  proving its immediate context or the â€˜res gestaeâ€™â€ or the â€œuncharged offense 
  is â€˜so linked together in point of time and circumstances with the crime charged 
  that one cannot be fully shown without proving the other . . .â€™ [and is thus] 
  part of the res gestae of the crime charged.â€Â Â  And where evidence is admissible 
  to provide this â€œfull presentationâ€ of the offense, â€œ[t]here is no reason to 
  fragmentize the event under inquiryâ€ by suppressing parts of the â€œres gestae.â€

Id.  at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 370-71 (quoting United States v. Masters, 
  622 F.2d 83, 86 (4th Cir. 1980)).
Simmonsâ€™ act of burglarizing Thompsonâ€™s home was â€œinextricably intertwinedâ€ 
  with his attempt to evade Brooks, and his subsequent capture by the police.Â  
  Adams, 322 S.C. at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 371.Â  The information regarding 
  the Brooks burglary was relevant to show the complete, whole, unfragmented story 
  regarding Simmonsâ€™ crimes and capture.
III.Â  MISTRIAL/CURATIVE 
  INSTRUCTION
Simmons maintains the trial court erred in denying his motion for 
  a mistrial.Â  He claims he was prejudiced by the presentation of evidence regarding 
  the Brooks burglary, especially in light of the fact that the trial court granted 
  his motion for a directed verdict on the Brooks matter.Â  We disagree.
At the end of the Stateâ€™s case, Simmons moved for 
  a directed verdict of acquittal on the charges concerning the Brooks burglary.Â  
  Simmons argued there was no evidence Brooksâ€™ home was entered, and the indictment 
  failed to allege that the shed outside Brooksâ€™ home was a building appurtenant 
  in order to qualify for burglary.Â  The trial court granted the directed verdict 
  as to the Brooks burglary and petit larceny charges, finding there was a lack 
  of evidence to support the charges.Â  Simmons then requested a mistrial, contending 
  the jury had heard the evidence regarding the Brooks burglary, the evidence 
  should not have been admitted under State v. Lyle 
  [1]  because there was not clear and convincing proof of the Brooks burglary, 
  and it had tainted the jury.Â  The trial court denied the motion for a mistrial, 
  finding the Brooks burglary constituted a â€œcontinuous eventâ€ and the State was 
  entitled to present the Brooks evidence in order to show how Simmons was apprehended.
Simmons requested â€œa curative instruction or some other instruction to the 
  jury as far as what they can consider or not consider as far as the second burglary.â€Â  
  The trial court instructed the jury as follows:
I need to advise you at this time that the court has granted 
  a motion for the defendant for a directed verdict and I have dismissed indictments 
  2000-GS-40-45786 and 787 which were the charges of burglary at [Brooksâ€™ address] 
  and the petty larceny that accompanied that charge.Â  So, I have granted a directed 
  verdict in favor of the defendant on those charges.Â  They are not to be considered 
  by the jury for any purpose for the remainder of this trial.Â  Weâ€™ll continue 
  with the trial at this time.Â Â  
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound discretion 
  of the trial judge.Â  State v. Cooper, 334 S.C. 540, 514 S.E.2d 584 (1999);Â  
  State v. Crosby, 348 S.C. 387, 559 S.E.2d 352 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. 
  granted (Aug. 7, 2002); State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 522 S.E.2d 
  845 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The courtâ€™s decision will not be overturned on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.Â  State v. Harris, 
  340 S.C. 59, 530 S.E.2d 626 (2000); State v. Kelsey, 331 S.C. 50, 502 
  S.E.2d 63 (1998); State v. Arnold, 266 S.C. 153, 157, 221 S.E.2d 867, 
  868 (1976) (the general rule of this State is that â€œthe ordering of, or refusal 
  of a motion for mistrial is within the discretion of the trial judge and such 
  discretion will not be overturned in the absence of abuse thereof amounting 
  to an error of law.â€).
â€œThe power of a court to declare a mistrial ought to be used with the greatest 
  caution under urgent circumstances, and for very plain and obvious causesâ€ stated 
  into the record by the trial judge.Â  State v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 28, 
  236 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1977); see also State v. Beckham, 334 S.C. 
  302, 513 S.E.2d 606 (1999) (granting of motion for mistrial is extreme measure 
  which should be taken only where incident is so grievous that prejudicial effect 
  can be removed in no other way); Patterson, 337 S.C. at 227, 522 S.E.2d 
  at 851 (mistrial should only be granted in cases of manifest necessity and with 
  the greatest caution for very plain and obvious reasons).Â  A mistrial should 
  only be granted when â€œabsolutely necessary,â€ and a defendant must show both 
  error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.Â  Harris, 
  340 S.C. at 63, 530 S.E.2d at 628; see also State v. Council, 
  335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) (mistrial should not be granted unless absolutely 
  necessary; to receive mistrial, defendant must show error and resulting prejudice).Â  
  â€œThe less than lucid test is therefore declared to be whether the mistrial was 
  dictated by manifest necessity or the ends of public justice.â€Â  State v. 
  Prince, 279 S.C. 30, 33, 301 S.E.2d 471, 472 (1983).
The trial judge did not abuse his discretion in denying Simmonsâ€™ 
  motion for a mistrial.Â  The evidence presented regarding the Brooks burglary 
  showed that Brooks heard a noise, chased a suspect, and directed police to the 
  location where Simmons was apprehended.Â  This evidence was relevant to Simmonsâ€™ 
  capture and would have been admissible at trial regardless of whether Simmons 
  faced charges for the Brooks incident.Â  Thus, Simmons suffered no error or resulting 
  prejudice from the admission of this evidence.
Moreover, the trial judge instructed the jury to disregard the evidence 
  regarding the Brooks burglary.Â  Generally, a trial judgeâ€™s curative instruction 
  is deemed to cure any error.Â  See Kelsey, 331 S.C. at 75, 502 
  S.E.2d at 76; Patterson, 337 S.C. at 226, 522 S.E.2d at 850; State 
  v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 479 S.E.2d 517 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The trial judge 
  in the present action thoroughly instructed the jury that Simmons no longer 
  faced burglary or petit larceny charges in connection with the Brooks burglary 
  and they were not to consider that evidence in any way.Â  Concomitantly, we find 
  any alleged error in failing to declare a mistrial was cured.
IV.Â  PRIOR BURGLARY/HOUSEBREAKING 
  CONVICTIONS
Simmons argues the trial court erred in allowing the State to present 
  evidence of his prior burglary/housebreaking convictions as an element to support 
  first degree burglary.Â  Because Simmons agreed to stipulate that the burglary 
  occurred at night, he contends it was unnecessary for the State to additionally 
  prove his prior convictions.Â  We disagree.
Prior to trial, Simmons moved to exclude evidence of his prior burglary/housebreaking 
  convictions because the charged burglaries in the case sub judice 
  occurred at night.Â  Therefore, the State could prove the â€œnighttimeâ€ element 
  of first degree burglary instead of proving the â€œtwo or more prior convictionsâ€ 
  element.Â  Simmons asserted the prior housebreaking convictions were more than 
  ten years old, thus outside the ten year time limit, and were prejudicial.Â  
  The State informed the trial court that Simmonsâ€™ prior record included a 1981 
  guilty plea to three counts of housebreaking; a 1983 conviction for common law 
  burglary, on which he later received post-conviction relief; and a 1998 guilty 
  plea to first degree burglary. 
Simmons offered to stipulate to the â€œnighttimeâ€ element.Â  After reviewing State 
  v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 526 S.E.2d 228 (2000), the trial court denied Simmonsâ€™ 
  motion.Â  The trial court limited the State to proving the prior record and ordered 
  it not to go into the details. 
At the end of the Stateâ€™s case, Simmons and the State agreed to stipulate that 
  the jury could be told Simmons had â€œtwo or more prior convictions for either 
  burglary or housebreaking.â€Â  The stipulation was subject to Simmonsâ€™ objections.Â  
  The trial court read the stipulation to the jury:

The State and the defense have entered into a stipulation 
  that the defendant in this case has two or more prior convictions for either 
  burglary or housebreaking.Â  These convictions are as follows: 1981, three counts 
  of housebreaking and in 1998 one count of burglary.Â  Now, I will further instruct 
  you that you are not to consider the prior convictions about which I have just 
  mentioned through the stipulation, you are not to consider these prior convictions 
  as evidence that the defendant committed the crimes for which he is currently 
  on trial nor should you consider the convictions as character evidence; that 
  is, you should not conclude that because the defendant has been convicted of 
  burglary and housebreaking previously that he is likely to have committed these 
  offenses for which he is currently charged.Â  You are to consider these prior 
  convictions simply as part of the elements that the State must prove in order 
  to make out a charge of first degree burglary.Â  And Iâ€™ll tell you the law on 
  first degree burglary at the conclusion of the case when I am instructing you 
  in the law.

After the jury instruction, Simmons renewed his motions.
 First degree burglary is defined, in part, as 
  follows:

  (A) A person is guilty 
    of burglary in the first degree if the person enters a dwelling without consent 
    and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling, and either:

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   . . . .

  
    (2) the burglary is committed by a person with a prior record of two or more 
  convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination of both; or
  

       (3) the entering . . . occurs in the nighttime.Â  
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (Supp. 2001).
The State is required to prove all the elements 
  of first degree burglary beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  State v. Benton, 
  338 S.C. 151, 526 S.E.2d 228 (2000).Â  â€œ[B]ecause two prior burglary and/or housebreaking 
  convictions are an element of first degree burglary under Â§ 16-11-311(A)(2), 
  the defendant cannot require the State to stipulate to the prior convictions 
  in lieu of informing the jury about the prior convictions.â€Â  Id. at 155, 
  526 S.E.2d at 230; see also State v. James, 346 S.C. 303, 307, 
  551 S.E.2d 591, 592 (Ct. App. 2001), cert. granted (Nov. 15, 2001) (the 
  State cannot be forced to â€œstipulate generally to the prior offenses or to the 
  fact that the defendant had the legal status to be charged with first degree 
  burglary because such a stipulation might cause a substantial gap in the evidence 
  needed for the jury to find the defendant guilty of the offense.â€); State 
  v. Hamilton, 327 S.C. 440, 443, 486 S.E.2d 512, 513 (Ct. App. 1997) (finding 
  â€œthe two prior convictions were an element of the crime for which Appellant 
  was charged.Â  As such, the State was required to prove the two prior convictions 
  and could not be forced to accept Appellantâ€™s offered stipulation.â€).
However, to ensure that the defendant is not convicted 
  on an improper basis while allowing the State to prove the elements of first 
  degree burglary, the trial court should limit the evidence to the prior burglary 
  and/or housebreaking convictions.Â  Benton, 338 S.C. at 156, 526 S.E.2d 
  at 230-31.Â  Detailed, particular information about the prior burglaries and/or 
  housebreaking convictions should not be admitted.Â  Id.Â  In addition, 
  the trial court should, on request, instruct the jury that the information should 
  only be considered for the limited purpose of proving one of the elements of 
  first degree burglary.Â  Id.
This Court recently considered an identical argument in State 
  v. Cheatham, 349 S.C. 101, 561 S.E.2d 618 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In Cheatham, 
  the defense offered to stipulate that the burglary occurred in the nighttime 
  and moved in limine to prohibit the State from introducing the defendantâ€™s three 
  prior burglary convictions.Â  The trial court denied Cheathamâ€™s motion and allowed 
  the State to introduce evidence of both the â€œnighttimeâ€ and the â€œprior record 
  of two or more convictions for burglaryâ€ elements of first degree burglary.Â  
  The Court articulated:

It is well settled the admission of prior burglary or housebreaking 
  convictions for limited consideration as an element of first degree burglary 
  does not constitute undue prejudice.Â  Thus, the admission of Cheathamâ€™s prior 
  burglary and housebreaking convictions as an element of first degree burglary 
  does not constitute unfair prejudice in this case.Â  Further, the trial judge 
  specifically instructed the jury not to consider Cheathamâ€™s prior convictions 
  as evidence of the Patel burglary and to limit their consideration of the prior 
  convictions to whether an element of first degree burglary was proven.Â  We find 
  no error in the admission of the convictions because the trial court took every 
  precaution to prevent the improper consideration of Cheatham's convictions and 
  to guard against undue prejudice.
Moreover, we find no merit to Cheathamâ€™s assertion that because he was willing 
  to stipulate to the â€œnighttimeâ€ element of first degree burglary, the State 
  should have been limited to proving only the â€œnighttimeâ€ element and it was 
  unnecessary for the State to present any evidence of the â€œtwo or more convictions 
  of burglary or housebreakingâ€ element.Â  As previously discussed, the State is 
  not required to accept a defendantâ€™s stipulation of proof because the State 
  still bears the burden of proving every element of a crime beyond a reasonable 
  doubt.Â  Despite Cheathamâ€™s attempt to stipulate that he met the legal status 
  to be charged with first degree burglary, we believe the trial court did not 
  err in denying his request to limit the State to proof of only the â€œnighttimeâ€ 
  element.

Cheatham, 349 S.C. at 109-110, 561 S.E.2d at 623 (internal citation 
  omitted).
As in Cheatham, Simmons maintains the State should have been 
  prohibited from submitting evidence of his prior burglary/housebreaking convictions 
  because evidence existed that the present burglary occurred at night.Â  The trial 
  court did not err in allowing the State to introduce evidence of Simmonsâ€™ prior 
  burglary/housebreaking convictions because proof of such prior convictions constitutes 
  an element of first degree burglary.Â  Because the State bears the burden of 
  proof, it was not required to prove only the â€œnighttimeâ€ element of first degree 
  burglary.Â  Further, Simmons agreed to stipulate to the convictions and their 
  admission.
Simmons claims his prior housebreaking convictions should not have 
  been admitted because they were more than ten years old.Â  Whether a conviction 
  should be admitted at trial due to its age is a question most often seen in 
  evaluations of impeachment evidence under Rule 609, SCRE.Â  In this instance, 
  a record of a prior conviction is an element of the statutory crime.Â  
  There is no requirement in the statute that the prior conviction be of a certain 
  age in order to allow admission.Â  There is no merit to Simmonsâ€™ argument.
The trial court properly limited the introduction of Simmonsâ€™ prior 
  burglary/housebreaking convictions to listing the conviction.Â  The jury was 
  not informed of the specific details of the crimes or convictions.Â  Finally, 
  the jury was instructed that they should consider the convictions only as proof 
  of an element of first degree burglary and that they were not to consider the 
  convictions as proof that Simmons was guilty of the current crime.Â  We find 
  no error.
CONCLUSION
We hold that where the offenses charged in separate indictments are of the 
  same general nature, involving connected transactions, closely related in kind, 
  place and character, the trial judge has discretion to order the indictments 
  tried together, over the objection of a defendant, absent a showing that the 
  defendantâ€™s substantive rights were violated.
The joinder of offenses in one trial is proper if the offenses (1) 
  are of the same general nature or character and spring from the same series 
  of transactions; (2) are committed by the same offender; and (3) require the 
  same or similar proof.
The trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to sever the two burglary 
  charges against Simmons.Â  Both indictments arose out of a single chain of events, 
  were of the same nature, and were proved by the same evidence and witnesses.Â  
  Furthermore, evidence of the Brooks burglary was necessary for full presentation 
  of the case without fragmentation.Â  The trial judge did not err in denying Simmonsâ€™ 
  motion for a mistrial.Â  Moreover, the judgeâ€™s curative instruction to disregard 
  the evidence as to the Brooks burglary cured any alleged error in failing to 
  declare a mistrial.Â  Finally, the trial court properly allowed the State to 
  present evidence of Simmonsâ€™ prior burglary/housebreaking convictions as an 
  element to support first degree burglary.Â  Accordingly, Simmonsâ€™ convictions 
  are
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and CURETON, J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).

THE STATE 
  OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Gregg M. Gallagher, as Personal Representative 
          of the Estate of Eleanor L. Evert,        
          Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert C. Evert, as Personal Representative 
          of the Estate of George C. Evert,        
          Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From 
  Horry County
  Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion 
  No. 3573
  Heard October 10, 2002 â€“ Filed November 25, 2002

REVERSED and REMANDED IN PART
& VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
        Fredrick Scott Pfeiffer, of Greenville; 
          and William A. Bryan, of Surfside Beach, for Appellant.
        David J. Gundling, and H. Randolph 
          Haldi, both of Pawleys Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Â The 
  central issue in this case is whether the estate of a surviving spouse who had 
  filed her elective share claim may receive that share when the surviving spouse 
  dies before the determination of her elective share.Â  We hold that the estate 
  is entitled to the share.
FACTS
Husband and Wife married in April of 1993.Â  Husband 
  died testate on January 5, 1998, survived by Wife and a son, Robert Evert, from 
  a previous marriage.Â  Husbandâ€™s will dated June 26, 1990, which was admitted 
  to probate on February 23, 1998, named his son as personal representative and 
  sole heir.Â  On May 1, 1998, Wife filed an Election by Surviving Spouse to take 
  an elective share of Husbandâ€™s estate.Â  Wife died on May 18, 1999, and her son 
  from a previous marriage, Gregg Gallagher, was appointed personal representative 
  of her estate.Â  Gallagher brought this action in probate court in his capacity 
  as personal representative of her estate to recover Wifeâ€™s elective share.  [1] The probate court denied the elective 
  share to Wifeâ€™s estate, holding that the elective share was intended to provide 
  for the surviving spouse during the remainder of her lifetime â€œso as to prevent 
  the surviving spouse from becoming a ward of the state.â€Â  It further found that 
  the elective share â€œwas not intended to be employed so as to augment an estate 
  for the benefit of heirs.â€Â  Finally, the probate court held that any claim for 
  an elective share was fully satisfied by non-probate assets.Â  However, the probate 
  court ordered Husbandâ€™s estate to pay Wifeâ€™s estate $8,000 as reimbursement 
  for a previous estate debt paid by Wife and also ordered Husbandâ€™s estate to 
  pay attorneyâ€™s fees to Wifeâ€™s estate.Â  Both parties appealed to the circuit 
  court.Â  
On May 26, 2000, the circuit court issued an order 
  affirming the probate courtâ€™s denial of the elective share, reversing the probate 
  courtâ€™s grant of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wifeâ€™s estate, and reversing the probate 
  courtâ€™s decision to reimburse Wifeâ€™s estate with $8,000.Â  While the circuit 
  court found the probate court erred in concluding the right to an elective share 
  does not survive the death of a surviving spouse, it affirmed the denial of 
  the elective share finding â€œit would be absurd to hold that the heirs of Mrs. 
  Evertâ€™sÂ  estate should be entitled to the benefits of an elective share simply 
  because the surviving spouse made the election during her lifetime.â€Â  The circuit 
  court found the result unjust, as well as absurd, and placed particular significance 
  on the fact that Wife received over $219,000 in non-probate assets.Â  
Gallagher served a motion to alter or amend the 
  circuit courtâ€™s order pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  The circuit court denied 
  the motion and Gallagher now appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Wifeâ€™s 
  estate was not entitled to her elective share of Husbandâ€™s estate, that it was 
  not entitled to an $8,000 loan repayment from Husbandâ€™s estate, and that it 
  was not entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Timeliness of Gallagherâ€™s appeal to Circuit Court
As an initial matter, 
  we address Evertâ€™s argument that Gallagher failed to timely appeal the decision 
  of the circuit court by failing to provide the circuit court proper notice of 
  his motion to alter or amend judgment as required by Rule 59(g), SCRCP.Â  Evert 
  contends that because a copy of the Rule 59(e) motion was not provided to the 
  circuit court within ten days of the filing of the motion, the time for appeal 
  was not stayed, and thus this appeal is untimely under Rule 203, SCACR.Â  We 
  disagree. [2] Â  
Although the circuit court acknowledged that it 
  never received a copy of the motion until December 12, 2000, and â€œon this ground 
  aloneâ€ it could deny the motion, the circuit court went forward and considered 
  the matters presented in Gallagherâ€™s memorandum in support of the motion.Â  Because 
  the circuit court found it appropriate to hear the matter, we find no error 
  in the circuit courtâ€™s decision to decide the motion despite Gallagherâ€™s failure 
  to comply with Rule 59(g), SCRCP.Â  The notes to Rule 59, SCRCP, indicate that 
  subsection (g) was added â€œto help insure the judge is promptly notified that 
  the motion has been filed.â€Â  There is no indication that the failure to transmit 
  a copy of the motion to the circuit court affects the tolling provision of Rule 
  203(b)(1), SCACR.Â  Therefore, the time for filing the notice of appeal did not 
  begin to run until after the circuit court denied the motion on December 27, 
  2000.Â  After the circuit court denied the motion, only twenty days passed before 
  Gallagher filed his notice of appeal on January 16, 2001, thus Gallagher complied 
  with Rule 203(b), SCACR. 
II.Â  Elective Share
Gallagher 
  argues the circuit court erred in refusing to allow Wifeâ€™s estate to recover 
  her elective share of Husbandâ€™s estate.Â  We agree.
The issue of whether the heirs 
  of a surviving spouse are entitled to the surviving spouseâ€™s elective share 
  where the spouse applies for the share, but dies prior to its determination, 
  is an issue of first impression in this state.Â  We begin our analysis by considering 
  the language of the statute governing the elective share.Â  Section 62-2-201 
  provides that â€œif a married person domiciled in this State dies, the surviving 
  spouse has a right of election to take an elective share of one-third of the 
  decedent's probate estate.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-201(a) (Supp. 2001).Â  Additionally, 
  Section 62-2-203 provides that â€œthe right of election of the surviving spouse 
  may be exercised only during his lifetime by him or by his duly appointed attorney 
  in fact.â€ [3] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-203 (Supp. 2001).Â  

The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain 
  and effectuate the intent of the legislature.Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of 
  Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  
  â€œUnless there is something in a statute requiring a different interpretation, 
  the words used in the statute must be given their ordinary meaning.â€Â  Mullinax 
  v. J.M. Brown Amusement, Co., 326 S.C. 453, 458, 485 S.E.2d 103, 106 (Ct. 
  App. 1997).Â  â€œStatutes, as a whole, must receive practical, reasonable, and 
  fair interpretation, consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of lawmakers.â€Â  
  TNS Mills, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 624, 
  503 S.E.2d 471, 478 (1998).Â  If a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, 
  and conveys a clear and definite meaning, there is no occasion for employing 
  rules of statutory interpretation and the court has no right to look for or 
  impose another meaning.Â  Miller v. Doe, 312 S.C. 444, 447, 441 S.E.2d 
  319, 321 (1994).Â  â€œOn the other hand, where a statute is ambiguous, the Court 
  must construe the terms of the statute.â€Â  Lester v. South Carolina Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Commâ€™n, 334 S.C. 557, 561, 514 S.E.2d 751, 752-53 (1999).
When confronted 
  with this question, other jurisdictions with similar elective share statutes 
  have determined that when a surviving spouse has validly exercised her right 
  to the elective share, her personal representative may file a petition for the 
  elective share determination for the benefit of the surviving spouseâ€™s estate. 
  In Smail v. Hutchins, 491 So.2d 301, 302 (Fla. App. 1986), the court 
  found that â€œthe right to share in the decedentâ€™s estate is not lost if the surviving 
  spouse dies after the election but before the court determines the amount of 
  the elective share.â€Â  The Florida court rejected the argument that the heirs 
  and not the surviving spouse would benefit: 

While this argument has been recognized to prevent a personal 
  representative from exercising a deceased â€œsurvivingâ€ spouseâ€™s election, the 
  reasoning is unavailing here. That heirs of a surviving spouse may benefit from 
  an election is not determinative. What is determinative is whether the surviving 
  spouse validly exercised the election. Merely because a surviving spouseâ€™s 
  heirs may benefit from an election is no reason to deny the surviving spouseâ€™s 
  statutory right to choose the elective share. If a surviving spouse dies shortly 
  after receiving the elective share the heirs will most certainly be the primary 
  beneficiaries of the election. 

Id. at 303 (emphasis added) (internal citations omitted).
Pennsylvania addressed 
  a similar situation in Trezak v. Jierski, 661 A.2d 412 (Pa. Super. Ct. 
  1995), and determined that a surviving spouseâ€™s heirs could pursue her elected 
  but undetermined share.Â  The Pennsylvania Superior Court found â€œthere was no 
  reason in law or equity why the claims of a surviving spouse, now deceased, 
  being pursued by her heirs, should be weakened by death.â€Â  Id. at 413.Â  

Similarly, the Nebraska Supreme Court has held that 
  once a surviving spouse petitions for her elective share that right becomes 
  vested.Â  


When a surviving spouse has petitioned for an elective share, 
  the right to pursue an elective share is no longer a surviving spouseâ€™s potential 
  personal right subject to abatement, but has become a right vested in 
  the surviving spouse. Therefore, if a surviving spouse dies after filing a petition 
  for an elective share . . . , the proceeding to enforce the spouseâ€™s election 
  as a vested right may be revived by the personal representative of the estate 
  of the spouse who has made the election but who has died before distribution 
  of property pursuant to the elective share.

Â In 
  re Estate of Stephenson, 503 N.W.2d 540, 545 (Neb. 1993).Â  
Significantly, Pennsylvania, 
  Florida, and Nebraskaâ€™s elective share statutes are similar to our elective 
  share statute in that the right of election may be exercised only during the 
  lifetime of the surviving spouse.Â  Furthermore, none of these statesâ€™ statutes 
  indicates an intent to provide for the needs of the surviving spouse only during 
  her lifetime. [4]  See 
  Fla. Stat. Ann. Â§Â§ 732.201, 732.2125 (Supp. 2001); Neb. Rev. State. Â§30-2137 
  (Supp. 2001); Pa. Stat. Ann. Â§Â§2206, 2203 (Supp. 2001).
When the elective share statute was enacted in 1987, 
  South Carolinaâ€™s common law did not require a spouse to devise any of her property 
  to a surviving spouse.Â  Thus, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-205 â€œis a statute of creation, 
  and strict compliance with its terms is mandatory in order to exercise the right 
  to an elective share.â€Â  Simpson v. Sanders, 314 S.C. 413, 415, 445 S.E.2d 
  93, 94 (1994).Â  We decline to construe the elective share statute to imply anything 
  other than the plain language it employs.Â  Our statute provides that the â€œelectionâ€ 
  of the share must be made during the surviving spouseâ€™s lifetime; thus, once 
  the spouse survives his or her spouseâ€™s death and makes the election, that requirement 
  is met.Â 
Moreover, we are inclined to agree with those jurisdictions 
  which hold that once a valid election is made, that right becomes vested in 
  the surviving spouse and would pass to her estate at her death.Â  In the absence 
  of any language in the statute to the contrary, we find that the type of interest 
  embraced by the elective share is a fee simple estate.Â  We find no support in 
  the statute or the case law for characterization of the elective share as a 
  life estate.Â  Accordingly, we hold a surviving spouseâ€™s estate may recover the 
  elective share when the surviving spouse dies after making the election but 
  before the probate court determines the share.Â 
  
  Because Wifeâ€™s estate was entitled to recover her elective share, we find the 
  circuit court erred in denying recovery of the share.Â Â  The circuit court held 
  that a recovery would be an absurd and unjust result due to the significant 
  amount of non-probate assets Wifeâ€™s estate received after Husbandâ€™s death.Â  
  However, we can envision numerous situations in which an absurd result would 
  occur if the elective share were denied to a surviving spouseâ€™s estate even 
  when a valid election has been made during the life of the surviving spouse.Â  
  For example, it would be absurd to deny Wifeâ€™s estate the right to recovery 
  here, but allow it if the Wife had died the day after the hearing determining 
  her share, but prior to the issuance of the final order.Â  
Â Our legislature has mandated that a surviving 
  spouse is entitled to recover an elective share unless the spouse has made a 
  valid waiver in writing.Â  See S.C. Code Â§ 62-2-204 (Supp. 2001).Â  â€œThus, 
  the legislature has indicated that the right to receive the elective share is 
  a substantial one.â€Â  Seifert v. Southern Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 
  305 S.C. 353, 357, 409 S.E.2d 337, 339 (1991).Â  Any benefits the surviving spouse 
  may obtain through non-probate assets of the deceased spouseâ€™s estate are immaterial 
  to the surviving spouseâ€™s right to seek an elective share of the estate.Â  Therefore, 
  it was improper for the circuit court to consider the non-probate assets.
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Debt Repayment
Gallagher next argues the circuit court erred in reversing 
  the probate courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees and the $8,000 debt repayment.Â  
  Specifically, he argues the circuit court lacked jurisdiction to decide these 
  issues.Â  We agree.Â  
South Carolina Code 
  Ann. Â§62-1-308(a) (Supp. 2001) requires that notice of an intent to appeal from 
  the probate court to the circuit court must be filed and served within ten days 
  after receipt of the probate courtâ€™s written order.Â  The statute further requires 
  that the grounds for appeal must be filed and served within forty-five days 
  after receipt of the written order.Â  Evert received the probate courtâ€™s final 
  order on September 7, 1999, but did not file his notice of intent to appeal 
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees and debt repayment until October 4, 1999.Â  Furthermore, 
  Evert did not file and serve his grounds for appeal until November 2, 1999.Â  
  Because he did not timely appeal from the probate court, the circuit court lacked 
  subject matter jurisdiction to address these issues.Â  Accordingly, we reinstate 
  the probate courtâ€™s order awarding the $8,000 debt repayment and attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to Wifeâ€™s estate. [5] Â  See Witzig v. Witzig, 325 S.C. 
  363, 366-67, 479 S.E.2d 297, 298 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding respondentâ€™s appeal 
  from the probate court to the circuit court not timely filed, thus, reinstatement 
  of the probate courtâ€™s order was required).
CONCLUSION
We find the circuit court erred in determining 
  that Wifeâ€™s estate was not entitled to pursue her elective share from Husbandâ€™s 
  estate and remand to the probate court for a determination of the elective share. 
  Additionally, we vacate the circuit courtâ€™s ruling with respect to attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and debt repayment and reinstate the probate courtâ€™s award of the fees 
  and $8,000 to Wifeâ€™s estate. 
REVERSED and REMANDED IN PART, and VACATED IN PART.
GOOLSBY and HOWARD, 
  JJ., concur.




 
   [1]
  Wifeâ€™s claim as an omitted spouse was 
    denied by the probate court, which found that Husband adequately provided 
    for her outside of the will, leaving her with $219,351.99 in non-probate assets.Â  
    Gallagher does not appeal the denial of the omitted spouse claim. 

 
   [2] Initially, we questioned whether 
    Evert preserved this issue for our review because he never made a motion to 
    dismiss to the circuit court for failure to comply with Rule 59(g)Â  See 
    Holy Loch Distrib., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 531 S.E.2d 282 
    (2000) (stating in order to preserve issue for appellate review issue must 
    have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge).Â  However, because 
    the issue goes to the circuit courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction to hear 
    the motion, we address the merits of Evertâ€™s argument.Â  See Brown 
    v. State, 343 S.C. 342, 540 S.E.2d 846 (2001) (stating issues raising 
    questions of subject matter jurisdiction may be raised for the first time 
    on appeal).

 
   
    [3] We foreclose any question that Wife was not a surviving spouse as 
    contemplated by the statute as she did not fall within any of the categories 
    that defines who is not to be considered a surviving spouse under S.C. Code 
    Ann. Â§ 62-2-802(b) (Supp. 2001).

 
   
    [4]  Only one state, New Jersey, holds a contrary view.Â  Unlike South 
    Carolina and other states, the New Jersey elective share statute is a â€œneed 
    basedâ€ statute, â€œwhich differs significantly from the Uniform Probate Code 
    from which the elective share is derived.â€Â  In the Matter of the Estate 
    of Bilse, 746 A.2d 1068, 1092-93 (N.J. Super. Ct. App. Div. 2000).Â  New 
    Jersey courts have interpreted the â€œprimary purpose of the statute may not 
    be simply to provide an inheritance to the survivorâ€™s heirs.â€Â  Id. 
    at 1092.Â  Because New Jersey uses an augmented estate method in determining 
    the amount of the elective share, the effect is to â€œgrant a share [to the 
    surviving spouse] only to the extent that is required for support.â€Â  Id.

 
   [5]
   We note that the probate court erred 
    in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to Wifeâ€™s estate.Â  As a general rule, â€œattorneyâ€™s 
    fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or statute.â€Â  Dowaliby 
    v. Chambless, 344 S.C. 558, 561, 544 S.E.2d 646, 647-48 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
    There is no statutory provision that allows for the recovery of attorneyâ€™s 
    fees for elective share proceedings.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302 
    (Supp. 2001).Â  However, as Evert failed to appeal the propriety of the award, 
    this is now the law of the case.Â  See Buckner v. Preferred Mut. 
    Ins. Co., 255 S.C. 159, 161, 177 S.E.2d 544, 544 (1970) (stating an unchallenged 
    ruling, â€œright or wrong, is the law of the case and requires affirmanceâ€).
